item.title: Labels in input fields aren‚Äôt such a good idea
item.description:
There‚Äôs something that‚Äôs been bothering me lately. It seems to be some kind of form interface trend where the labels for text inputs are placed inside the fields themselves.

Example:

There might be some pros

Admittedly, this makes an interface slicker. It saves space where you‚Äôd usually have a label, then some padding, then the input field and probably a load of padding around the lot.

But what you‚Äôre gaining in a clean look, you‚Äôre completely losing through a total lack of usability.

So, I‚Äôm an interface idiot

You know the lowest common denominator, idiot users that we design easy interfaces for? The ones that need to be led by the hand, step by step, across your design to get to the call-to-action?

That‚Äôs me, that is. I am an incredibly na√Øve user. I skim read, I‚Äôm forgetful, I barely pay attention and when I do I‚Äôm easily confused.

This is what I see

Here‚Äôs an example from a site that is otherwise a shimmering beacon of awesomeness over the wasteland that is the web:

Project Noah

As part of Project Noah, you upload photos of nature. The aim is to identify the creature or plant in your photo, and part of that is providing the relevant links to that species‚Äô page on Wikipedia and the Encyclopedia of Life.

It‚Äôs a beautiful interface, but I have an issue. I‚Äôll go and paste in a URL, then I‚Äôll select the other text box:

Then I have this thought:

Did I put the URL in the right box? Is Encyclopedia of Life the top input or the bottom input? How do I find out?!

It seems pedantic, but I genuinely do get this sense of panic that I‚Äôm entering it wrong and there‚Äôs no way to check that I‚Äôm doing it right. I have to click back outside the input box, so it no longer has focus, to check what the label was again.

WordPress

Another example from an interface that I use on a regular basis and generally love. In the 2.8 redesign of the WordPress admin, which is generally a huge amount better than before, the post editor title lost it‚Äôs label.

Before:

After:

The problem is that the first input box you‚Äôll click into is the top title input. It actually auto-focuses, and some clever script means that it puts the label back in after the auto-focus, but then the second you start typing you‚Äôve lost that label. If you start typing, then backspace because you made a mistake, you‚Äôve lost that label:

Designers often make assumptions

It‚Äôs all very well to assume that the user will remember that the title belongs in that box, but what if it‚Äôs somebody has cognitive difficulties? What if it‚Äôs someone that‚Äôs just an idiot like me who clicks into boxes without paying attention to the label first?

It started as an example

Originally we used pre-entered text in an input field as an example, to help users understand the input required. WordPress itself has a great example of this on the Writing Settings page in the WordPress admin:

These fantastic triggers mean that users who aren‚Äôt necessary technically minded can see the type of input that‚Äôs required to set up post via email, match that to the information they have and easily enter it into the boxes.

When did these useful triggers become a way to hinder users, instead of help them?

The rise of the HTML5 placeholder leaves room for abuse

HTML5 has a fantastic new form input attribute for adding placeholder information into the input boxes so that you can easily give your users cues without the need for JavaScript or CSS hacks:

Edit: ‚Äú*name*‚Äù should actually be ‚Äú*id*‚Äù here in the text input, I always get those two mixed up! (Thanks Mike, for the heads up)

But it‚Äôs not the same thing!

A label tells you what a form input requires, a placeholder gives you an example of the input required.

I‚Äôm no accessibility expert, but I can imagine the loss of a label isn‚Äôt going to help with screen readers. Forgetful people and people with cognitive disabilities will also struggle.

Please think of daft people like me

It might beautify your interface and make you look modern and cool, but a label isn‚Äôt the same as a prompt. We need to keep our forms as clear as possible and not let cool technology take over the understanding of basic user behaviour.

I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôm alone in struggling with using these inputs, but I‚Äôd love to know everybody else‚Äôs opinions.

While it looked clean, it was confusing as to what it was after you click inside the box, and it wasn‚Äôt obvious how to send the search query (mainly because‚Ä¶well, there was no longer a search button). Not everything is obvious to everyone. Even though the design *could* look nicer without labels, a true designer will find a way to make them work visually.

      1. Layout your form with paired label and input combinations as normal. 2. Use a safe offscreening technique on your labels to maintain accessibility and satisfy your visual requirements. 3. item.title: Future Of Web Design 2011 ‚Äì; The Review
item.description:
Another great event from Carsonified, I really enjoyed Future Of Web Design this year.

The Cost

I was actually really lucky to get a ticket. I seriously couldn‚Äôt afford the ¬£714 2-day conference pass, even at the super early bird rate (that was about ¬£200 less, I can‚Äôt remember exactly.) My lovely friend Scott Coello had done the amazing motion graphics for the conference and very kindly gave me his spare ticket.

I think the price is actually a shame. Whilst there is no doubt that the FOWD and FOWA events are longer, with a better venue and far better food than most events, the price dictates a particular type of attendee. There seemed to be far more corporate and agency employees whose bosses can afford the mega ¬£s. This seems to reflect in more attendees who are there because they‚Äôre told to be there, there‚Äôs less socialising, less enthusiasm and far more people working behind laptops than there have been at smaller, less expensive conferences I‚Äôve attended over the last year or so.

The Talks

It was disappointing that there were talks that I‚Äôd seen versions of before. No doubt speakers vary and evolve their talks from one event to another, but I had seen a few of them at New Adventures back in January and the titles of their talks seemed similar so I ended up giving them a miss. I guess that‚Äôs the issue with living in a small country where speakers don‚Äôt have so far to tour!

Fortunately, the benefit of Future Of Web Design is the fantastic Track Two. Track Two features up-and-coming speakers who aren‚Äôt necessarily experienced at conferences but always bring fresh faces and ideas. It was on this Track Two that I first saw Aral Balkan speak last year (and it‚Äôs no surprise he was on the main track this year, he‚Äôs got presenting skills like nobody else.) This year I saw some great speakers including Ian Stewart, Ian Hamilton, Femi T Adesina and John McGarvey.

Running Themes

Whilst a wide breadth of topics is a great way to cover lots of areas in different talks, compared to other conferences such as dConstruct or New Adventures, which both had basic themes running throughout, FOWD felt a little disjointed and less cohesive. Some talks were high-level with conceptual themes whereas some were more hands-on instructional lectures.

This varied from feeling refreshing to jarring across the range of talks and I imagine this probably was a reflection on how comfortable I was with each subject. More ideas-based talks are informative and inspirational no matter how familiar you are with the topic as it‚Äôs always the fresh opinion of the presenter. On the other hand, I found talks that touched on actual code or ‚Äòhow to do this to be successful‚Äô grew wearing when you feel like it‚Äôs something you already know.

The People

The more I go to conferences, the more I enjoy the company of the other attendees. As soon as you know a few people, it becomes much easier to be introduced to others and before long you feel like you know almost everybody. I think I‚Äôve also gained confidence over the last couple of years, I‚Äôm happy to go and introduce myself to new people and this really makes a difference. Having people to discuss new ideas and socialise with in real life, rather than on Twitter, can be refreshing!

Will I go next year?

Unfortunately I don‚Äôt think I will. FOWD is a brilliant conference but the price is just too high. I can‚Äôt give up nearly the same amount that I pay myself for a month‚Äôs work on two days out where I‚Äôm earning no money.

I‚Äôll definitely go to other conferences, and I‚Äôm all set for Ampersand next month, but I think I‚Äôll keep ¬£200 as my maximum ticket price per-day in future (well, until I‚Äôm making a fortune!)

item.title: Yeah, so what if I live-tweet at conferences?
item.description:
I‚Äôve been at Future Of Web Design

The last two days were long, but fantastic, experiences at Future Of Web Design. The talks were high quality, loads of cool people were there and I learnt a lot.

Problem is, (from some people‚Äôs point of view) I tweeted a lot. I‚Äôm not going to stop, but I thought I should explain why live tweeting isn‚Äôt just ‚Äútrying to make yourself look clever by tweeting everything you hear.‚Äù (Got that from a hilariously passive aggressive tweet that wasn‚Äôt directed at me.)

Taking conference notes

First off, there‚Äôs the selfish factor. I‚Äôm a serial note-taker. Some people learn by doing, some people learn by watching, I‚Äôm one of those people who mostly learns by writing it down. No idea why, it just goes in and gets stuck that way.

But why on Twitter?

I used to write pages of notes, but I‚Äôd rarely read them again, and nobody else could make use of them.

Not everybody can afford to go to conferences. As a freelancer, I certainly can‚Äôt afford to go to many (and I couldn‚Äôt have gone to FOWD without the awesome kindness of Scott Coello giving me his spare ticket..)

Since I started the occasional live tweet passing comment on points in talks around two years ago, I started getting a few people saying they liked keeping up with the main themes of the conference despite not being there, and asking if I was going to live tweet the next events. I love the idea of helping people out like this, it‚Äôs not cool missing out on fantastic ideas and knowledge.

Trust me, I am paying attention

The bizarrest tweets I‚Äôve seen are those saying live-tweeters can‚Äôt be paying attention. How?! You‚Äôve got to pay attention to be able to tweet. Today I managed to live-tweet a talk and be the most active member of the crowd in talking to the speaker at the same time…I‚Äôm spend my life constantly multitasking with technology, why would a conference be any different?

I‚Äôm not trying to look clever, or cool, or show off

Anybody that‚Äôs knows me well knows I don‚Äôt really care about being clever, coolness isn‚Äôt really my thing and I care more about people thinking I‚Äôm a nice person than anything else.

I don‚Äôt really think live-tweeting makes me look anything. Maybe noisy…yeah, noisy.

See, I wouldn‚Äôt just do it if it was annoying everybody

I can totally accept that some people don‚Äôt like tweets from conferences. To be honest, if most of my followers complained then I probably wouldn‚Äôt do it (reluctant as I am to be a slave to Twitter followers, ‚Äôcause that‚Äôs what the unfollow button is there for, right?) but I get so many more saying they find it handy.

I‚Äôm not keen on making followers grumpy but I‚Äôd much rather make some followers happy.

I try not to tweet everything

I‚Äôm only using a phone and I don‚Äôt have lightning fingers so I couldn‚Äôt possibly tweet everything that comes out of a speaker‚Äôs mouth. I try to pick the most interesting, vital to the theme of the talk, and (most importantly) points I understand. I‚Äôll almost always put my own angle on it, as it‚Äôs how I interpret it, and to fit it into 140 characters!

I try as hard as possible to keep the tweets in context

It can be hard keeping in context. I‚Äôm in that environment, fully immersed, it can be tricky to distance yourself. I haven‚Äôt really had any complaints about them being confusing, but I guess people are more likely to ignore the tweets than complain that they‚Äôre nonsense.

It‚Äôs really just a conference in bitesize

I find it really useful when I‚Äôm writing up conference blog posts to go back through these chunks to remind what the talks were all about. At New Adventures, and now for FOWD, I check out ubelly‚Äôs tweets as well. Between us, I reckon we‚Äôve got the live-tweeting covered!

But what if you hate the live tweets but you like me the rest of the time?

Get a decent desktop/iPhone Twitter app, such as Echofon, and use the mute user or mute hashtag feature. It‚Äôs a cool temporary way to hide me, conference tweets, and any other occasionally irritating tweeters, without going through the hassle/potentially embarrassing unfollow/refollow process.

And if all else fails…just unfollow me!

I don‚Äôt use Twitter directly to please other people. If you‚Äôre not keen on me then chances are we won‚Äôt get along! Whilst I might be sensitive if a real friend unfollows, I understand that my particular brand of babbling nonsense isn‚Äôt for everybody.

And to be honest, not using any unfollow trackers or paying too much attention to follower figures, I‚Äôll probably never know…

item.title: Notebooks and Getting Over Moleskine
item.description:
I‚Äôm a notebook and sketchbook-aholic. Actually I‚Äôm addicted to stationery of any kind. Pens, pencils, post-it notes. It‚Äôs incredibly easy to convince myself I need these items when I mostly don‚Äôt.

Notebooks and sketchbooks (and maybe some nice accompanying pens), however, are an absolutely vital part of my working life.

Why bother with physical notebooks?

Evernote isn‚Äôt the same as writing by hand. Neither is any other note-making software. Balsamiq isn‚Äôt the same as wireframing by hand, or Photoshop for sketching. Neither is any other wireframing or design software. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm being books-have-to-be-paperback nostalgic here, but I can‚Äôt type rough notes or sketch rough drawings as quickly on the computer as I can by hand.

When email can‚Äôt be your record

I know a lot of us rely on email as a second memory. A lot of detail from various projects, discussions with clients, usernames and passwords are all findable by searching email. But what about those (horror horror) face-to-face meetings or phone calls? Notebooks are great for quickly jotting down the gist of things in an easy-to-interpret way.

You don‚Äôt have to worry about hierarchy as you would on note taking software (text mostly has to go from top to bottom, not laid out randomly across the page) and you can mix sketches and written notes without having to switch apps. (Fancy that! Old school!)

It‚Äôs not about making it neat

One of the stigmas that I find are attached to Moleskines is the idea of the ‚Äòperfect‚Äô designer‚Äôs notebook. You¬†envisage¬†perfect neat pages of beautiful flowing joined handwriting or elaborate wall-worthy pen-and-ink drawings. I don‚Äôt know about everybody else, but my sketchbooks are filled with barely-legible scratchy notes and wireframes so wonky that you start to wonder whether browsers are available in parallelogram shapes.

}}

(The ‚Äúperfect‚Äù style Moleskine page, from Flickr)

It‚Äôs not about making it tidy, it‚Äôs about trying to get ideas out as quickly as possible without being held back by formatting. I can‚Äôt imagine most people show their sketchbooks to anybody else. For me it‚Äôs almost like a diary. You can see how many more rubbish ideas I come out with over good ones…

What‚Äôs the perfect notebook?

There was a time when I was so anti-hipster that I wouldn‚Äôt buy a Moleskine. I think I‚Äôve just about got over myself now, and a couple of years ago I indulged in my first overly expensive, but lovely, notebook. It was all about the squares. I couldn‚Äôt find another decent notebook with squared paper.

Why squares rock my world

Want to write along horizontal lines? You can do that with squares. Want to draw some quick wireframes that are slightly straight? Squares are perfect. The XLarge Moleskine squared notebook was my champion.

The new perfect notebook

Recently I decided I wanted to go for something different. I saw the Leuchtturm1917 (nope I‚Äôve got no idea how to pronounce it, either) notebooks on The Paperie and I was wooed by the idea of a pretty coloured notebook.

So I bought myself a lime green large squared notebook. Along with a little pen holder, as I could get it in a matching colour. This notebook is lovely.

The squares aren‚Äôt all the way up to the edges, like the Moleskine, it has margins at the top and bottom of each page and a space for the date. It has contents pages for you to fill in and comes with labels so you can index your notebooks. It isn‚Äôt quite as big as a XLarge Moleskine, but is a more manageable size than the larger¬†Leuchtturm1917 notebooks and, being hardback, it makes it easier to handle.

Probably most importantly, the squares are more subtle. Moleskine squares are bold and black and you notice their presence. With the¬†Leuchtturm1917, the squares are so subtle that once you‚Äôve used a page, you barely notice them behind the contrast of ink pen. This would make it much better for pencil drawings as they‚Äôd definitely be harder to see on the Moleskine counterpart.

 

What was this post?

This post was a love fest. I love my new notebook and I wanted to tell the world. Is it anti-linkbait to write a post that isn‚Äôt being hateful? I like that idea…

This one runs really well for writing and sketching as it‚Äôs very liquid. However, for drawing, I prefer any old cheap black biro. item.title: The Big M
item.description:
First off, let me declare my complete bias. I‚Äôve been involved with the Big M conference from pretty early on, I was lucky enough to do all the design work and the organisers are lovely guys who I‚Äôm proud to call my friends. I‚Äôm still on a high from how much I enjoyed myself (and just about recovered from the surreal feeling of being in a place with my own design work everywhere) so this is really going to be the most biased event review you‚Äôve ever read!

The Attendees

It was a complete mixture of attendees, ranging from business entrepreneurs to freelancers, mobile operators to web developers and UX experts. What really stuck out was that everybody seemed friendly, enthusiastic and engaged in the day. I didn‚Äôt spot any boring/bored looking ‚Äòsuits‚Äô and it made for a fun atmosphere.

The Venue

A great point made in Adam Bird‚Äôs review was that Komedia in Bath made for a great conference day venue as it usually hosts comedy and music events. Such a good point. The venue being a slightly dark and very colourful room made for a relaxed and informal feel to the conference. It was the right size for about 200 people so it didn‚Äôt feel over-crowded or empty at any point. The chairs were a bit hard, but I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever been to an event where that wasn‚Äôt a problem…

The Speakers

As a designer, and a previous attendee of the openMIC events, I usually expect most of the talks to go over my head. I‚Äôm not a big business brain, never really worked in the mobile industry and mobile development is a lot more complicated than the majority of web markup/frontend development that I do. However, this wasn‚Äôt the case at all at The Big M.

The speakers were all experienced presenters. Often you‚Äôll find one ‚Äòdud‚Äô talk at a conference, but there wasn‚Äôt one here. Whilst some of the speakers presented on more controversial topics that I wouldn‚Äôt necessarily agree on, each made their points well, engaging the audience and inspiring loads of discussion in the Q and As and breaks.

Here‚Äôs a brief rundown of some of the main points (and some of my terrible iPhone photos) I tweeted from the talks as well as some brilliant tweets from @bigmconf where all the talks were live-tweeted:

Raam Thakrar ‚Äì;¬†App distribution and monetisation ‚Äì; the only things more important than lines of code

Thakrar: We need to think about why a consumer buys a phone, what part we play in the decision & how can we monetise this From @bigmconf

software and apps are now a deciding factor when people are buying handsets, so app devs should use this to work with operators

Thakrar: Specific lessons: develop an app that consumers love and thus influences their choice about what they do with their money From @bigmconf

Aral Balkan ‚Äì;¬†Beyond Usability on Mobile

The differentiating factor that allows Apple to charge more for phones, tablets, mp3 players and PCs is user experience

Usable is akin to being edible (credited to @Cennydd and @aarron)

Common sense is a dangerous myth

Panel: led by Dan Appelquist ‚Äì; Openness: Open Standards/Source/Data in Mobile

Openness is about giving developers choice so they can come to one platform and create content they can use on other platforms From @bigmconf

Openness: At some point you are going to die and your work is going to live on, but the only way it can do that is to be locked in From @bigmconf

Openness often hits the barriers of brand protection and content protection From @bigmconf

Bruce Lawson ‚Äì; Breaking out of the ‚ÄúWalled Garden‚Äù: HTML5 and open technology for mobile development

When using new web technologies, make use of them, but don‚Äôt rely on them. Always use progressive enhancement

Consider using <a href=‚Äùtel:xxx‚Äù> for linking phone numbers to be click-to-call on mobile

Accessibility isn‚Äôt just about being legal, it‚Äôs a moral obligation

Ewan MacLeod ‚Äì;¬†State of the Union ‚Äì; Mobile Address

Apps being separate from the handsets and operators are barriers to the most useful mobile experiences. It needs to be seamless

Thakrar: Specific lessons: develop an app that consumers love and thus influences their choice about what they do with their money From @bigmconf

Thakrar: Specific lessons: develop an app that consumers love and thus influences their choice about what they do with their money From @bigmconf

Paul Golding ‚Äì; Future Innovations In Mobile

Golding: There is a myth that being first is really important. You want to be the first to win not the first to market From @bigmconf

Golding: Study what else has succeeded, what has failed, and what you can take and project out in order to innovate From @bigmconf

Golding: You need to conceive the product, choose the platform, develop the product, deliver the product and engage the market From @bigmconf

No Wifi!

For the conference day of The Big M there was no wifi and very little 3G or Edge signal (O2 isn‚Äôt much good in Bath!) This is the second conference I‚Äôve been to this year without wifi (the other being New Adventures) and I think it‚Äôs a great choice that more conference organisers should make.

Mike quite rightly pointed out that even when organisers pay for expensive wifi, it usually gets overloaded, and is an additional cost that the attendees pay in their ticket price. I couldn‚Äôt agree more. Having so little signal meant people were talking to each other rather than being stuck to laptop screens. There was just about enough signal for the occasional tweet about the event but not enough for any anti-social so-and-sos to sit and work!

The Workshops

Day Two was a smaller affair, with about a quarter of Day One‚Äôs attendees returning for the workshops. I was really lucky to go to Aral Balkan‚Äôs iPhone Design Principles and half of Patrick Lauke‚Äôs *HTML5 and Mobile *before we had to head back home to Surrey.

Aral Balkan ¬†‚Äì; iPhone Design Principles

Aral really is a talented presenter. After a quick introduction of everybody in the room, he managed to pitch a perfect level workshop helping us to understand the different development choices you have when creating web apps and native apps for the iPhone. I wrote pages and pages of notes and feel like I understand the development process so much better now (and that‚Äôs considering I‚Äôm no programmer, just a designer!)

Patrick Lauke ‚Äì; HTML5 and Mobile

The first half of this was a great intro to HTML5 and expanded on many of the points that Bruce made in his talk the day before. As someone who is already using HTML5 on most projects, I found a lot of the talk was probably better suited to those just getting to know HTML5 but the great explanations of concepts such as the viewport really helped cement what I already knew.

All in All

I knew Chris and Mike would run a fantastic event, and I hope this encourages more smaller and informal conferences. Conferences that freelancers can afford that enthuse, engage, feed, water and inspire. Here‚Äôs hoping there might be a Big M II…

item.title: Women in‚Ä¶
item.description:
I‚Äôve changed my mind about this subject!

To read about why and how I don‚Äôt believe this anymore, please read Women and conferences.

Business‚Ä¶Tech‚Ä¶Conferences‚Ä¶

Every time I hear these dreaded phrases, ‚Äú*Women in business*‚Äù, ‚Äú*Women in tech*‚Äù, ‚Äú*Women at conferences*‚Äù I just groan. It‚Äôs really boring.

Examples. ‚Äú*There‚Äôs only x% of women at this conference*‚Äù or ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no female speakers at this conference.‚Äù Not just as observations (there‚Äôs nothing wrong in stating the obvious,) but saying it‚Äôs a negative point. I couldn‚Äôt care less how many other girls there are at a conference.

Asides from it being a complete bonus when there‚Äôs no queue for the Ladies, I‚Äôd rather a conference was full of eager people who bought their tickets because they were interested and wanted to engage with other attendees. Would you rather there were 100% enthusiastic, participatory attendees or a conference where there was 50⁄50 male/female attendees where 30% were just there to make up the numbers and weren‚Äôt bothered about being there?

As for speakers, maybe there are more male leaders (not exclusively, there are some brilliant female speakers) in the industry. The quality of a conference shouldn‚Äôt be compromised just in order to get some female speakers. Get the best speakers you can, and just don‚Äôt discriminate against having great women when they do emerge.

Don‚Äôt get me wrong, I do understand people who are working for female equality. I appreciate it. I‚Äôm not really a feminist, as nowadays feminism seems to mean that men can‚Äôt say or do anything and women can act like female-equivalent of chauvinists as they like (See Loose Women and other embarrassing examples.)

I find being singled out as female isn‚Äôt the same as being equal. Reverse discrimination isn‚Äôt as positive as it often seems. Gender is completely irrelevant in the tech industry, certainly at conferences and definitely in business. We‚Äôre not talking about manual labour or track running here, where women and men are clearly different. Why should women be remarkable just for existing in these industries?

As a designer, I don‚Äôt think my design work reflects my gender. Certainly cultural and environmental factors must impact on my work, but design work is about context. Design work reflects the context of the project and the context of the client. I don‚Äôt like pink because I‚Äôm female but I might use pink on a site if I think it‚Äôs appropriate. I don‚Äôt think you could tell I‚Äôm a girl just by looking at my work (though correct me if I‚Äôm wrong, because if you can then I‚Äôm doing something wrong!)

There‚Äôs issues with most industries being male or female-dominated. That‚Äôs not going to change overnight. But in the same way, I really can‚Äôt say that anything in business, tech or conferences have ever put me off being a part of it. There are so many factors affecting genders in work, be it education, culture, or actual discrimination. Let‚Äôs just get rid of the discrimination part, and when it‚Äôs not a problem, let‚Äôs not make it an issue.

And finally, let me be completely honest. If anybody talks about me as being a ‚Äúwoman in business‚Äù, a ‚Äúwoman in tech‚Äù or a ‚Äúwoman at a conference‚Äù, not only is it weird being referred to as a woman (I‚Äôm not that old!) but I also find it pretty fucking patronising.

item.title: New Adventures 2011
item.description:
Conferences are my social life

As I go to more conferences, I meet more lovely people and get to see friends I‚Äôd only ever talk to on Twitter otherwise. In the last two years, I‚Äôve been to about three a year and it feels about the right amount that you rarely see the same talk twice and it‚Äôs not just the same topics going round.

Again, I met loads of great people at New Adventures, but unfortunately missed more people than I meant to catch up with. It was such a packed-out venue that it was easy to lose people in the crowds!

The location and venue

It didn‚Äôt take too long to get to Nottingham from Surrey. We were lucky that the motorways were reasonably clear and we spent most of our time trying to navigate Nottingham‚Äôs one way systems when we got there! It was good to go to a conference outside London but the resulting hotel and petrol costs for me (I can commute to London easily) made it almost as expensive as attending more expensive conferences in London.

The venue, Albert Hall, looked beautiful and made it easy to hear and see the speakers wherever you were sat. For me, the downside to the venue was that I was really cold for most of the day. I know I feel the cold more than most, but it was a bit uncomfortable sitting there in a scarf and gloves. Often conferences are warm environments due to the amount of people in one room so I admit I was probably under-prepared for the wintry day!

The talks

Twitter

There wasn‚Äôt any wi-fi at the conference, which was great because there were less faces hidden behind laptops (it‚Äôs really distracting when you‚Äôre sitting behind someone writing code!) However, this did mean there was less back channel discussion on Twitter, it was mostly people quoting favourite quotes. It was a bit of a shame as I like the back channel. It gives people the confidence to bring up issues and questions that they wouldn‚Äôt necessary ask the speakers in front of the crowd.

I made use of the 3G signal on my phone to make notes on Twitter about the conference, it‚Äôs the way I learn and helps me digest ideas (I‚Äôm a complete fidget.) I know I‚Äôm likely to irritate people by doing it, but a few said they liked to hear some of what was going on so I think it‚Äôs much more worthwhile than keeping it to myself. These notes, along with the great tweets from the brilliant @ubelly, helped me form some connections between the ideas and help me understand them better.

(You might want to click the image to see it larger so you can read the really dinky text.)

Unlike my notes on dConstruct, I wanted to connect the different themes running through the talks as they made the day so much more than just random talks.

Running themes

So many of the talks felt as though they were revolving around connected themes. This made the day feel as though you were getting different sides of the story which suited the half hour slots which might have otherwise felt brief. Particular themes such as user experiences, emotional design, narratives and content-aware design made me feel very grown up. Much like dConstruct, it seems like the conference circuit is moving on from the slightly patronising¬†show-and-tell¬†and instructional talks to more inspiring, motivating and thoughtful discussions on how we can be better and make the industry move forward.

My favourite talk: The New Language of Web Design

I‚Äôd say my favourite talk (though I enjoyed them all) of the day was Dan Rubin‚Äòs. The topics of language, communication and terms in the industry felt just right for the audience and the maturity of the conference. Dan is a consistently fantastic speaker and his was the one talk that really stood out as being the perfect amount of exploration into the subjects for the half hour slot.

I‚Äôll be looking out for New Adventures next year…

One thing can be sure, Simon Collison put on a great conference. There was a really friendly, we‚Äôre-all-in-it-together, casual atmosphere that was fun and in no way intimidating to new conference goers.

As a lot of the bigger conferences are becoming more expensive with little added value, less expensive conferences like New Adventures are in competition to provide a great time at a freelancer‚Äôs price tag. It definitely achieved that, feeling like a premium conference on a very affordable budget.

If there‚Äôs a New Adventures next year, I‚Äôll definitely try to be there.

item.title: Hardboiled Web Design and Transcending CSS
item.description:
My history with Transcending CSS

In 2006/early 2007 I read this amazing book. I was half way through my first year studying Digital Design, and I‚Äôd only been experimenting with standards-based web design for about six months after reading Web Standards Solutions.

I was already well on my way to being a standards fiend, but Transcending CSS by Andy Clarke did, literally, transcend the standards and made me utterly mad about pushing the boundaries of CSS.

Transcending CSS covered properties I‚Äôd never heard of before, like z-index, and Andy Clarke wrote it with such complete conviction that you couldn‚Äôt argue with his points for progressive enhancement. I read it twice over and kept it on my desk for about two years. My only issue was that there wasn‚Äôt any index, so I wrote my own contents for the frequently-referenced pages in the front of the book in pencil.

Anticipating Hardboiled Web Design

In the early days of Transcending CSS, I wasn‚Äôt on Twitter and I didn‚Äôt much follow the ‚Äòindustry‚Äô around web design. I wasn‚Äôt really sure who Andy Clarke was, I just knew that he wrote this book I really liked.

Three years later and I‚Äôm a full time freelance designer, always on Twitter, and always trying to keep up with the latest and greatest in the most practical way possible. When Hardboiled Web Design was announced by Five Simple Steps, I‚Äôll admit I was pretty excited. I loved A Practical Guide to Designing For The Web (also by Five Simple Steps) which only made me keener.

I followed all of Andy‚Äôs tweets about #hardboiledwebdesign so I knew what to expect from the book. As I‚Äôm now following the goings-on of HTML5 and CSS3 a lot closer, I knew it probably wouldn‚Äôt have the same appeal as my wow-this-is-what-the-web-can-really-do awe of Transcending CSS, but it still didn‚Äôt disappoint.

Hardboiled Web Design

The book is predictably well-written. It‚Äôs not too formal, not overly-instructional and very friendly. That‚Äôs already an improvement on the majority of books about web development. Sometimes the tone is a bit scary-in-a-good-way, you can really tell how much Andy cares about pushing the web forward.

The book is themed around detective stories. I found the detective novel references a bit much at times, but that‚Äôs because I‚Äôve never read any (not that I wouldn‚Äôt, I just haven‚Äôt!) It started to feel a bit like an in-joke I wasn‚Äôt a part of, but did make for lovely illustrations and content examples.

Worth it for the inspiration alone

The first quarter of the book is dedicated to telling you why you bother with new innovations in web development. You‚Äôre loaded with ways to persuade your clients or bosses to go along with it too. If you‚Äôve been um-ing and ah-ing about using HTML5 or CSS3 then this chapter is for you. Even if you haven‚Äôt, like I hadn‚Äôt, it‚Äôs really valuable to have someone else put forward the arguments in an easy-to-understand way.

HTML5, CSS3 and the rest

The HTML5 and CSS3 examples are great. I found some of the CSS a bit hard to follow through reading alone, as not every code example had an accompanying image to illustrate it, but it was great to read in front of a text editor. As soon as you try out the examples in the book yourself, it all becomes much clearer.

What really was the big thing for me was the inclusion of microformats. I‚Äôve been working with microformats for a couple of years and I‚Äôm smitten. Anything that helps me write better, more semantic, more useful markup is my thing. It‚Äôs really good to see microformats getting the attention and explanation they deserve. Andy does them justice and gives some really useful examples, especially on combining different specifications.

Different formats

I bought the bundle package from Five Simple Steps that included the book itself, a PDF version (available for instant download) and a poster.

I liked the idea of having the PDF for reading using iBooks on my iPhone and iPad. This was a bit of an issue, as the PDF has the same layout as the book itself, including very wide margins. This made for easy reading at full size on my mac, slightly eye-straining use on my iPad and a right nightmare on the iPhone. To read the text on iPhone, you have to zoom about a lot. Alongside constant scrolling to read the full width in the page, it‚Äôs not the most comfortable reading experience.

I don‚Äôt necessarily think it should have been designed for these small devices! I‚Äôm just saying that I wouldn‚Äôt buy the PDF if iPhone usage (or even iPad, really) was what you had in mind.

No index again!

Again, the biggest issue for me was the absence of an index. With a book so full of useful examples, I‚Äôm constantly flicking through trying to find the example I remembered from the first read. Having the PDF is useful, as you can use a search function to find what you‚Äôre looking for, but fiddling about opening PDF files isn‚Äôt really for me when I could just grab the book from next to my desk. So, I‚Äôve gone back to the old-school and have started sticking postits in as bookmarks. I like the idea that it looks like a much-loved textbook!

Should you buy Hardboiled Web Design?

Absolutely, without a doubt, yes.

Alongside HTML5 For Web Designers, I think that Hardboiled Web Design would go a very long way to prepare a web designer (designer-developer) for all these amazing new technologies.

Not only do you get the low-down on how to use it, you get the most important arguments of why and when that seem to be holding so many designers back.

item.title: Design work is 50% visual, 50% justification
item.description:
After I finished my last post about Design Tips for Developers, it really struck me¬†how much I wrote to justify my design. I wasn‚Äôt just writing tips saying¬†‚Äú*do this, it‚Äôs good*‚Äú,¬†‚Äú*don‚Äôt do this, it‚Äôs bad.*‚Äù I put time and effort into explaining why I made these decisions and why I didn‚Äôt do it another way.

When I send a design to a client via e-mail, I usually spend around 45 minutes ‚Äì; 1 hour writing an accompanying ‚Äòjustification‚Äô. I really have no idea if I‚Äôm the only one that does this? I assume not. I know a lot of people don‚Äôt, they just send static images. Does this mean it‚Äôs not worthwhile?

How I do justifications

Here‚Äôs an excerpt from my last post, giving a classic example of how I write justifications:

I‚Äôve limited the ‚ÄòLatest Happenings‚Äô to only five events on my design. My reasoning being that if you have many more than that, they‚Äôre not really ‚Äòlatest‚Äô anymore. This way we can ensure that the amount of happenings are well-balanced with the content on the left side of the page. Although the ‚ÄòWhat is Lift?‚Äô content is liable to changing, I imagine that it wouldn‚Äôt increase too much more in length, as any further information and you‚Äôre going into the depths of documentation that probably isn‚Äôt suitable for a home page.

I try to cover all the basics of the design. I explain my choices regarding layout, typography, colour and imagery. I summarise any other methods or angles I tried that didn‚Äôt work, and explain why I thought they didn‚Äôt work. If I‚Äôm not actually sure why I did something on impulse, I‚Äôll really think about it, analyse my decision and explain it to the client.

Why I write justifications

  1. #### Not all design work can speak for itself

Clients aren‚Äôt design specialists so you can‚Äôt expect them to ‚Äòget‚Äô your thinking behind a design just by looking at it (And you probably couldn‚Äôt expect most other designers to ‚Äòget‚Äô it either!)

  1. #### I don‚Äôt often get to speak to the client in person

It‚Äôs fairly easy to quickly summarise your design when you can look at a person‚Äôs face and see if they understand you. When you‚Äôre lacking face-to-face communication, you really have to make up for it in writing.

  1. #### Even if I do see a client face-to-face, I‚Äôll often forget something

Sitting down and writing a proper explanation helps me look over the design from top to bottom and take it apart. It also takes a while for a client to mull over a design. They might be unsure of part of it later on at home. Having your justification there to reassure them can be helpful.

I was also taught how

Every now and again I realise the huge value in being taught art and graphics at school, college and university. From secondary school art lessons onwards, one-third of the work was research, one-third was the practical application and the final third was evaluation. Even if the rest of the work wasn‚Äôt perfect, if the evaluation was good then you‚Äôd be on to a winner. It wasn‚Äôt about being skilled with a pencil or paintbrush, it was about being able to reflect, evaluate and actually understand what you were trying to achieve.

Being able to give a reason

I believe a huge part of your ability as a designer is understanding why you do what you do. In order to create an appropriate and usable design, you‚Äôve got to be able to do better than ‚Äòpretty.‚Äô

I think a designer should be able to tell a client the reasoning behind their design decisions. There‚Äôs nothing worse than the ‚Äòprofessional‚Äô who says ‚ÄúI like it best like this and I‚Äôm the professional so you should respect my opinion.‚Äù Of course, everybody has their own preferences, theories and leanings, but if you can‚Äôt come up with a reason beyond ‚ÄúI like it‚Äù or ‚Äúeverybody‚Äôs doing it‚Äù, then what service are you actually providing?

Value for a client

Reading a description about your design decisions lets a client know you‚Äôve really thought their design through. I‚Äôm hoping I show my clients that I spend a long time considering my design work and trying to make something that will work for them. When you‚Äôre providing a service, rather than a physical product, it‚Äôs good to remind people that you‚Äôre good value for money.

Value for a designer

After sending a justification I find there are fewer arguments. Full stop. As I‚Äôve got better at writing them, I‚Äôve found more clients agree with my decisions. I hope I‚Äôm also improving as a designer, but it‚Äôs also incredibly difficult to disagree with a design element when someone has given you a very good logical reason why it works.

I don‚Äôt get ‚Äúmake my logo bigger‚Äù, ‚Äúcan you do another version?‚Äù or ‚ÄúI want it in Papyrus‚Äù. I know I‚Äôm fantastically fortunate to work with lovely people, but I reckon explaining yourself (and maybe being a bit persuasive) might also have something to do with it.

item.title: Design Tips For Developers
item.description:
This little post is based around the talk I gave at Bathcamp. Rich Quick came up with the great idea that, whilst Bathcamp attendees are mostly developers, a talk on design for developers was probably appropriate.

And you might have seen on my post from last week, I was looking for a case study to use in my talk. As happens with everything, I just didn‚Äôt have time to include the case study in the talk, so I thought I would blog it here as a follow-up from Bathcamp.

The original

Tim Perrett had been asking me for a while to help redesign liftweb.net. Even though the design isn‚Äôt awful, and I‚Äôm not even sure whether it was done by a developer, it did need some designery love.

My redesign

I wasn‚Äôt aiming for a full-on redesign, more of a re-alignment of the existing design. I tried to take all the elements that I thought were successful, and continue using those, and try to improve on the areas that I thought had issues.

I‚Äôll explain my decisions below, based on my design tips for developers. I‚Äôm only including the most relevant tips from my talk, as very few designs would cover all of them!

My Design Tips For Developers

  1. ### Design isn‚Äôt all about having an ‚Äòeye‚Äô

A lot of people just have an ‚Äòeye‚Äô for design. Knowing what looks good to the masses comes fairly easily. This doesn‚Äôt mean that if you don‚Äôt have that ‚Äòeye‚Äô, you can‚Äôt design. A lot of design principles are based on simple theories and rules that anybody can follow.

All good designers know the rules, the best designers know how to break them effectively.

  1. ### Colour

Contrast is the most important aspect of colour when you‚Äôre trying to make text readable

The inconsistency in colour contrast was fairly noticeable on the original Lift page. In some places, it was dark on light and in some places it was light on dark, this makes sense.

However, in the ‚ÄòTaking Off‚Äô, ‚ÄòFlying in Formation‚Äô, ‚ÄòTeam‚Äô and ‚ÄòWiki‚Äô pages, the descriptions are black on a dark gradient background. This makes the text harder to read, as well as drawing attention to this part of the text as it‚Äôs significantly different from the contrast patterns on the rest of the page.

Contrast is something that loads of designers get wrong, as well as developers. Silly things like light grey text on a white background, a big hit with print designers. Screens are incredibly inconsistent, and our eyesight is better saved for more important things than squinting at text on a screen.

I really recommend using Jonathan Snook‚Äôs Colour Contrast Check. This analyses the contrast between your foreground and background colours against the WCAG guidelines. Everybody knows that guidelines are just for guidance, so I wouldn‚Äôt stress if you‚Äôre colours aren‚Äôt AAA compliant (this produces very extreme contrasts that are pretty hard on the eyes) but if you make sure your colours are AAA compliant at 18pt+ then you should be on to a readable winner.

If you‚Äôre going to use a strong colour, just use one

With a lot of purples and blues teamed with white, the Lift page was suffering from a bit of a 90s colour scheme. The trick is to stay away from using multiple strong colours (the dark blue and purpley blue) together.

To calm a design like this down, I tried using less of the extreme colour contrasts (dark blue and white) and more of the in-between, softer and more muted colours. Where I felt the purpley blues and dark blues were a bit harsh, I just toned them down to a slightly greyer version.

I then used these colours to help differentiate between areas of content. The original Lift design did a good job of emphasising the quotes at the top of the page through using dark text on a light background, where the rest of the page used the inverse. I took this theory further.

Whilst I thought it was good to keep the quotes at the top of the page, as they‚Äôre vital to helping sell the benefits of Lift to potential high-profile groups, they‚Äôre not really as valuable as the four links below to ‚ÄòGet Started‚Äô, ‚ÄòLift community‚Äô etc.

As this content, and the content immediately below is most useful to the page visitors, I used the dark-on-light contrast to draw the user to those areas. It stands out more than the light-on-dark areas above as it is a greater contrast against the overall page background.

At this small size, you can see how my redesign colours draw the eye to the most important content

  1. ### Layout

Give everything more space, and share the space equally between the elements

When you look at the original design, what really jumps out is the huge amount of space in the middle of the page. This is caused by the amount of ‚ÄòLatest Happenings‚Äô appearing down the right hand column. Obviously, this wouldn‚Äôt have been originally designed like this, but it emphasises the importance of imagining how the content on a page may evolve.

I‚Äôve limited the ‚ÄòLatest Happenings‚Äô to only five events on my design. My reasoning being that if you have many more than that, they‚Äôre not really ‚Äòlatest‚Äô anymore. This way we can ensure that the amount of happenings are well-balanced with the content on the left side of the page. Although the ‚ÄòWhat is Lift?‚Äô content is liable to changing, I imagine that it wouldn‚Äôt increase too much more in length, as any further information and you‚Äôre going into the depths of documentation that probably isn‚Äôt suitable for a home page.

I felt that the ‚ÄòWhat is Scala?‚Äô and ‚ÄòLift Books‚Äô information was also a little hidden-away at the bottom of the ‚ÄòLatest Happenings‚Äô sidebar. I brought this out into its own area underneath the main content and gave it a light-on-dark contrast to clearly separate it from the content above. This also makes the text look less intimidating. As the areas are clearly separated, it doesn‚Äôt look like a huge amount to read.

Try to base your design around a grid

With some large areas of white space and some slightly squashed looking text in boxes, the structure of the original page design doesn‚Äôt look like it is based on a grid. However it is fairly simply laid-out and does have gridded elements to it.

Using a grid makes a lot of the design decisions less of a decision, as your grid will help dictate where the elements belong. Little details like having all the bottom of the text line up against a base grid, and main content areas having the same proportions, make a design look a lot cleaner and much classier.

Above you can see how I used a grid to line up all of my elements. I started with a main content area width of 960px. This is a useful value as it‚Äôs divisible by many different multiples, giving you nice round numbers to work with. It doesn‚Äôt really matter if you‚Äôre using pixels, ems or percentages, it‚Äôs just working from one value to get your proportions that helps.

The yellow grid lines are where I started, I divided my main content area into four, as this suited the four main calls-to-action (‚ÄòGet Started‚Äô, ‚ÄòLift Community‚Äô) well. Usually, I‚Äôd probably design around three columns as this corresponds well with the golden section which creates a very harmonious balance in your design. You can combine three and four column grids in one, but this is probably a bit complicated for this post!

All of my main content areas sit within these yellow columns. The logo is in the first column, the navigation in the next three columns. The testimonials sit in all four columns, and the calls-to-action each sit in their own column. The main content areas are split into two sets of two columns.

What might stand out to you is that the ‚ÄòDemo‚Äô and ‚ÄòDownload‚Äô buttons don‚Äôt sit entirely comfortably into columns. This is intentional. By moving some elements out of the column structure, it creates a tension against those that are within the columns, and draws attention to them.

The orange lines are an example of how I divided the columns further to decide where the margins should be. Each column of about 240px is divided by 4 and then those columns are divided by 2 again to get 30px, which is the width of the margin.

For areas like the width of the selected testimonial link, I just split the column by two as I needed a wider space to hold that text.

I also used the yellow grid lines for rows. It‚Äôs hard designing with rows on a web design as the content is always liable to change and no longer fit within those rows if there‚Äôs more or less text or an image gets put in. You can see that the content roughly sits on these rows by not completely.

I actually work on all web designs with a 10px square grid underneath as a baseline for all content, especially text. As most of the text has a line-height of 25px, every other line of text sits on the 10px grid. Below is what a small segment of the design looks like sitting on a 10px grid.

And that‚Äôs where the bananas go.¬†Just seeing if you‚Äôre still here!

Imagery

Avoid generic stock photography

I know the original page didn‚Äôt have any stock photography. In fact, I think that was the problem. There wasn‚Äôt any kind of imagery to break up the text. The closest it came was quote marks and gradients.

So first off I found some appropriate images to illustrate the content. A quick bit of Googling and I located the book covers for the Lift books. This will make the books easier to identify in passing, and really work to break up that text-heavy area at the bottom.

The difficulty in sites about web development and other non-visual subjects is there isn‚Äôt much in the way of obvious imagery you can use to illustrate your pages. But stay away from the stock photos! These are never the solution as they mostly look generic, cheesy and cheap.

Illustrations can be expensive, though stock illustrations are often better than stock photos. However there are a lot of high quality free icon sets out there. If you find icons relevant to the content, they can serve to break up a very text-heavy site and act as signifiers to help the user understand what the text, call-to-action or button is for.

I had a look through my icon collections and found some Shine icons that suited the content and were the right sizes for button links and bigger calls-to-action.

Use subtle patterns and textures to add depth to a page

I‚Äôd almost completed my design, and it felt like it was looking a bit flat. This is usually the way when you‚Äôre using a different solid colours. To combat this effect, I added some subtle noise and shadows to give it a more ‚Äòreal‚Äô feeling.

I know I‚Äôd usually say that something like ‚Äònoise‚Äô is possibly a current trend, but I think it‚Äôs more of a recent discovery. It‚Äôs all very well using grungy textures if it‚Äôs appropriate to your site, but it really wouldn‚Äôt be for most software, corporate or family sites. Subtle noise is a great way to add some texture and definition without theming a site. Just make sure it‚Äôs very gentle. It looks best when not instantly visible, it should be that subtle.

  1. ### Light

Choose one imaginary light source, and make the shadows follow that source

The thing that people forget when they use gradients, box shadows and text shadows on websites is that these elements are all used to recreate the illusion of light. Having light and dark on a site imitates real life, it makes your design more ‚Äòreal‚Äô, it makes it easier for your users to identify with it.

The incoming problems with CSS3 is that people are using shadows willy-nilly, chucking them in to make their design look fancy without thinking about the effect they‚Äôre creating. This is visible on the random text-shadow on the original Lift design.

If ¬†you want to use gradients and shadows to make your site feel more real, and give it more depth, the trick is to choose a natural-style imaginary light source, and make all your shadows follow that.

There could be two light sources, though that could quickly get complicated, and beyond the realms of CSS, so I just went with the simplest possible for my design‚Äì;top-down. I imagined there was a light behind/above me and so it was projecting shadows that were equal sizes on each side of the boxes. It might not be completely scientifically sound, but it‚Äôs close-enough to feel real.

Colour is also important. Since when have you seen a white shadow? Pure black shadows are also very rare unless it‚Äôs very very dark. A shadow is usually just a darker shade of the surface it‚Äôs casting on to, follow that principle and you‚Äôll have realism in no time.

Make your light source subtle

The other issue with the text shadow on the original Lift design is that it‚Äôs really screamingly obvious. From day-to-day we don‚Äôt really notice or comment on shadows much, even though they‚Äôre used everywhere, occurring in real life and almost every piece of software. The reason we barely notice is them is because they‚Äôre so subtle. I know I‚Äôve used the ‚Äòsubtle‚Äô word about a million times now but it really is the key to making a design look sophisticated.

  1. ### If in doubt, keep it simple

Less looks more sophisticated

There‚Äôs no crime in creating a site with a white background, and no crime in being ‚Äòbasic.‚Äô All the best sites are noted for their simplicity and how clean they look and not how garish and full-of-stuff (my particular design weakness) they are.

I really hope these tips and this sort-of walkthrough has been helpful. I‚Äôll be happy to do more in the future if anybody wants them, or further explain any more elements of this design if anybody asks.

item.title: Bathcamp plea for bad designs by developers
item.description:
I‚Äôve got a talk for Bathcamp 2010 in the works! Thanks to the ever-helpful Rich Quick for the idea, I‚Äôm going to do a talk on Design Tips for Developers.

However, alongside a bit of time, effort and available slot on the day, this is subject to some help from a kind developer. I‚Äôm looking for a bad design created by a developer to use as a case study.

I need a design by a developer

What I need

A single page design (can be part of a larger site) that was designed by a developer. It doesn‚Äôt have to be flashing-gif awful, but in need of some love and care. You know the phrase ‚Äúlooks like it was designed by a developer.‚Äù Something that looks like that!

What I‚Äôm going to do with it

The plan is I‚Äôll do a quick run-through of some easy-to-use tips, and then we can work together on improving an existing design using those tips. If the page is already in HTML and CSS, then I‚Äôll toy with the idea of doing it live. If it‚Äôs not (or if I‚Äôm feeling doubtful about my live-typing abilities) then I‚Äôll just pre-prepare some changes to the design that illustrate the points.

What you (as the generous donator of the design) will get

  • My eternal appreciation
  • A free redesign of that page
  • A full justification of all the design changes on that page, so they can be applied elsewhere if needed

What you (as the generous donator of the design) won‚Äôt get

  • Cruelty or embarrassment. I‚Äôm doing this as friendly tips and don‚Äôt have any interest in being mean to people. This will be constructive criticism only.

Willing to help?

E-mail me at bathcampdesign@laurakalbag.com, tweet me @laurakalbag or leave a comment below.

If more than one design is volunteered, I will choose the best (that can be most improved using the tips) and possibly use more than one if there‚Äôs some good ‚Äòuns and I have the time. ## 8 comments

item.title: Stuck on a design
item.description:
After discussing Dribbble and Forrst, and my latest post that looked at criticism in design, I‚Äôve been thinking a lot more about how feedback features in my design process.

Getting stuck

When I used to get stuck on a design, from ‚Äòcreative block‚Äô or a complete lack of inspiration, I would frantically brainstorm, then browse inspiration sites, then ask the opinions of other designers. Usually the feedback from other designers would form the basis of my amendments, I‚Äôd gain inspiration from those changes and continue work from there.

Somehow it didn‚Äôt feel right though, I didn‚Äôt feel like I was working for myself, asking other designers could feel a bit like cheating. I didn‚Äôt like how detached it made me feel from the design when I started to follow the ideas of other designers that have completely different approaches and styles from my own. I decided I don‚Äôt feel comfortable sharing work in those stages with other designers as they can be a negative influence on me. Not because they make bad suggestions, but because I work to satisfy them.

No longer craving that kind of approval, I‚Äôve realised that I make extensive use of two new types of feedback, client feedback and ‚Äòboyfriend‚Äô feedback.

Client Feedback

So it might sound totally obvious. Inevitably, you will always get feedback from the client at some point. However I‚Äôve found myself doing this at earlier and earlier stages since I starting working freelance.

Lately I‚Äôve been going straight into talking to the client as soon as the design slows down or is coming suspiciously quickly (usually a sign that I‚Äôve jumped on a bandwagon or just acted on my first, badly thought-out idea.) I came to the conclusion that there‚Äôs no point searching for answers so far away from the problem. The client is the one person who set the brief and will approve the results, they‚Äôre the beginning and the end, so why not involve them more in the middle as well?

Feedback now, polish later

Number one newbie mistake is showing a client a 100% complete mockup (or even live) page design. I‚Äôve done it, and kicked myself for it. Chances are you‚Äôll have really jumped on an idea and run with it. The problem is that the client might not like your angle or approach. You‚Äôve just wasted a huge amount of hours on something that is rejected outright.

You‚Äôre designing for the client

There‚Äôs no need to be fearful of showing something incomplete. Clients aren‚Äôt stupid, and if you explain that the work is unfinished but you‚Äôre looking for their input on what you‚Äôve done so far, they‚Äôre likely to be grateful that you‚Äôre keeping them in the loop.

Unfinished work doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean bad work either. You‚Äôre not posting your work online for the world to see, you‚Äôre sharing progress and developing designs.

The benefits of feedback now

If the client is finding it hard to understand your approach, or flatly hates it, you‚Äôve got time to discuss, justify, rework and whatever else is needed to create something that your client loves and you know will work for the user.

Design is just creative problem solving. If the client isn‚Äôt keen on what you‚Äôve shown them and you‚Äôve got some useful criticism, you‚Äôre further refining the problem which will help get you closer to the answer.

Boyfriend Feedback

As a freelance designer, I‚Äôm very lucky to have another person around me while I work. My boyfriend Matt works in the same room at home and is an honest critic of everything I do, whether I want his opinion or not!

Non-client and non-designer feedback

Matt is great at giving me reactionary critiques. In this way, he‚Äôs far more like a client or a user. He‚Äôll tell me he thinks it‚Äôs rubbish, and give a vague idea of why, usually based on reactions and associations such as ‚Äúit reminds me of X.‚Äù¬†Matt‚Äôs reasons are never because it‚Äôs not on trend, or it doesn‚Äôt make use of available technologies. In fact, he often hates the fashionable styles and can convince me to be more reasonable and not succumb to ‚Äúbut this looks pretty.‚Äù

One thing that struck me about the discussions about criticism on Dribbble, and the Gap logo, is that the type of feedback a designer gives is totally unlike the thoughts and opinions of clients and users. Those thoughts and opinions are exactly that. They‚Äôre not necessarily put in context or very constructive but they are the emotions and associations which are so hard to put into words but have a huge impact on your design‚Äôs effectiveness.

Community helps and hinders

I love the amount of apps and tools showing up to help designers communicate more effectively with other designers. It‚Äôs fun to share, and it‚Äôs fun to have a bit of mutual-appreciation going on. However I think I‚Äôm likely to fall into the trap of designing for these communities, for approval of other designers and developers, and totally forgetting the blindingly obvious user needs and client necessities.

Am I the only one? I think it‚Äôs hard to tell from the outside. Some people are very capable of creating work that is incredibly satisfying to users, clients, other designers and themselves. The order in which they aimed to please isn‚Äôt obvious!

For me, changing the way in which I frame my request for feedback has been a big help, both when talking to clients and with other designers. Instead of an entirely open invitation for critique (which may come later when the design is more complete), I usually try to pose very direct questions that identify the problems as opposed to recommending the solution. "Do you think the call to action should be more prominent?" or "What type of feeling does this color scheme evoke", etc. Your post also made me think about ownership of a design, and how there is a pride that goes along with coming up with the ideas and inventing the solutions. I think it's important to be aware of times when that sense of pride may conflict with the best interest of the project. Does that make sense? I also totally agree that it's helpful to have someone who is not the client or another designer, but who can be brutally honest to tell you what they think.

item.title: Good old designer snobbery is alive and kicking
item.description:
There‚Äôs one thing that I hate about being a designer and that‚Äôs the snobbery. Most, if not all, designers are a little bit guilty of looking down on other people‚Äôs work. Comments such as ‚ÄúPah! They used Comic Sans‚Äù or ‚ÄúErgh! Don‚Äôt they know reflections are so out of date now?‚Äù

These are comments I‚Äôm 100% guilty of saying, but I think the problem is the outlet. If it‚Äôs a quick chatter between friends then there‚Äôs not much lost except making yourself look like a bit of an arse, but start broadcasting these harsh judgements to the world and you‚Äôll rapidly give the impression of a big ego, huge mouth and tiny brain.

Dribbble Egos

I‚Äôve been feeling the need to unfollow people recently, when their Dribbble ego has been massively over-inflated. Dribbble is an exclusive community in its nature of being invite-only. However, far too many people see it as owning an invite means you are in some way superior to anybody that doesn‚Äôt have an invite.¬†As seen on Twitter:

Hey everybody, I‚Äôve got a Dribbble invite. Send me a link to your portfolio and I‚Äôll give my invite away to the best one.

What baffles me is that not many other people seem to think this is wrong.

What‚Äôs the point in a community of elite designers?

To sit and caress each other‚Äôs egos, ¬†posting shots mimicking each other and establishing trends, and to gawk at ‚Äòweblebrities‚Äô and instantly hit ‚ÄòLike‚Äô on anything they produce without even looking at it first.

Unfortunately, this is what a large part of Dribbble has become, partly due to the attitudes of those that send out tweets like above. There‚Äôs no value in a community where everybody is doing the same thing, adhering to the same rules and spending all day telling people how lovely they are. The best and most useful comments on Dribbble are those that offer constructive criticism. The most interesting shots are from previously unheard-of people because we‚Äôre being introduced to a new way of thinking, not the same old rut that the ‚Äòweblebrities‚Äô are stuck in.

And who are you to judge?

One of the things that irritates upsets me the most is that the aforementioned tweet comes with the assumption that the tweeter is better than those who are sending them their portfolios. Who are they to judge the quality of somebody‚Äôs work?

And even if the work is undeniably poor. Who are you to prevent these people from growing? One of the premises of the Dribbble community that really appealed to me was sharing criticisms with people you don‚Äôt know.¬†Having your work critiqued by somebody else helps you learn how other people see your work, introduces you to alternatives that you may never consider, and occasionally gives you a boost in self-confidence.

It works the other way round too. By constructively criticising other people‚Äôs work, you challenge your own perspective on design. By trying to come up with helpful suggestions and interpretations, you‚Äôre learning to understand more than ‚Äòlike this,‚Äô ‚Äòhate that.‚Äô This is how designers grow. Whether the criticism comes from clients or other designers, it‚Äôs all of value, and who is the tweeter above to deny other people the opportunity to indulge in such creative and useful practices.

The Gap Logo

Late last night the furore over the Gap logo redesign came about.

Scrivs puts it way better than I could but it seems like madness. The logo isn‚Äôt that bad. It‚Äôs average, and thus an improvement on 99% of logos in the world. Get some perspective!

So quick to be rude about other people‚Äôs work

Matt coined a great term for these type of people, ‚Äòkeyboard heroes.‚Äô The kind of people who are all full of bravado and aggression when they‚Äôre hiding behind a keyboard, but would stay quiet when talking to somebody‚Äôs face.

Again, we‚Äôre all guilty of this from time to time. Twitter is perfect for getting your snap judgements out there and having 140 character tantrums. None of these tweets said ‚Äúit would look better if they‚Äôd put some spacing between the letters‚Äù or ‚Äúa solid blue square would have tied in better with the old branding.‚Äù It was straight to spitting vitriol.

Could you do any better?

This is the classic. That the majority of people slating the Gap logo could certainly not do any better. How do you know what the brief was and whether the logo fits it? These people don‚Äôt understand the context so it would be very difficult to understand whether it delivers the desired effect. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a great logo, but I don‚Äôt think I could do much better without knowing what Gap were going for. I believe that unless you can do better, then maybe you should use your keen eye to help improve your own work.

item.title: Using Dribbble and Forrst for feedback on a client project
item.description:
A couple of weeks ago I created a quickie logo for Andy Warburton‚Äôs mobile stock photography service Stockyoo. Andy was really keen on the idea of using Forrst and Dribbble for posting the progress of the project to get the opinions of potential users of a stock photography service and do some early promo for Stockyoo itself.

Dribbble and Forrst

Dribbble and Forrst are part of a new wave of sites aimed at (mostly web) designers and developers. Dribbble allows its users to post 300 x 400px teaser snapshots of their work. Forrst has wider options of posting any image, URL, piece of code or question. Both encourage feedback from other users in the form of comments. Dribbble also encourages ‚Äòrebounds‚Äô where users can rework an existing snapshot and repost it.

I‚Äôve been a member on Dribbble since January and on Forrst since the beginning of August, and I was happy to post my work in progress. I‚Äôm not too much of an ego to have my work critiqued, and I thought it‚Äôd be a fun experiment.

The Process

I didn‚Äôt post every tiny iteration of the Stockyoo logo online as I thought it‚Äôd drive people mad. I had twelve images in total (all posted to Forrst) which covered four or five major iterations of the design. As soon as I felt ready to send something to Andy for feedback, that was when I felt ready to post the images online.

I posted as much identical information as I could to both Dribbble and Forrst. Generally, I could include a larger, more detailed image on Forrst as there‚Äôs no size limitation. I also posted more frequently to Forrst as it has no limit on posts, whereas Dribbble limits the amount of posts over a month (usually around twenty if you use them all.)

The Stats

Forrst

  • Posts ‚Äì; 12
  • Views ‚Äì; 80*
  • Likes ‚Äì; 34
  • Comments ‚Äì; 13

** I get the feeling this stat might be wrong, as on some posts I have more likes than views.*

Dribbble

  • Posts ‚Äì; 7
  • Views ‚Äì; 842
  • Likes ‚Äì; 14
  • Comments ‚Äì; 16

As you can see, the Dribbblers seemed more likely to give their opinion, but much less likely to ‚Äòlike‚Äô the post!

How Dribbble and Forrst feedback helped

Overall, there was a lot of approval and a positive reaction to my design. This was great as it made me feel as though I was heading in the right direction, and let Andy know that potential users of the site were keen on the logo.

Improving the lens

One aspect I had trouble with initially was the design of the lens. I hadn‚Äôt done anything quite like it before so needed some help with getting it right. Luckily, the lovely people on Forrst and Dribbble were willing to give me a hand!

lowercase, CamelCase or Other?

The original name for Stockyoo was ‚ÄòStockYoo‚Äô with the uppercase S and Y. When I did my first draft of the logo design, I just went straight for all lowercase as I found it easier on the eye. Andy (quite rightly!) pointed out that it needed some uppercase for consistency when showing the name without the logo, but said he‚Äôd be ok with just the uppercase S, so we put it to the vote on Dribbble and Forrst and got 100% preference for the lowercase ‚Äòy‚Äô.

Dropshadows

One area where the users of Forrst and Dribbble didn‚Äôt really help was on whether I used a strong drop-shadow behind the lens or not. A small detail, but opinion was divided so I really just had to weigh up the opinions and make the decision for myself. (Serves me right for being so lazy!)

Benefits of using Dribbble and Forrst for feedback

There are a lot of benefits for using Dribbble and Forrst for feedback if you‚Äôre not overly sensitive to criticism.

  • Affirmation for a client

If a client is unsure of their feelings, or needs an outside opinion, they can see the reactions of others and use those reactions to help affirm their own beliefs.

If other designers (especially if they‚Äôre part of the target audience) have positive feelings towards your work then it can help convince a client that you‚Äôre heading in the right direction, even if the client feels otherwise. *

Thoughtful opinions and inspiration

If you‚Äôre struggling with some design (or code on Forrst) other users might have that valuable insight or piece of inspiration to help you on your way. *

Early promotion

This is likely to be especially effective where the users of Dribbble or Forrst are your target audience. Getting an idea of how these users feel towards your brand is very valuable. You‚Äôll make them feel more important for asking them how they think, and giving them a part to play in the creation of the brand is likely to create a feeling of ownership and loyalty.

The negative side

  • Time

It takes a reasonable amount of time to post to Dribbble and Forrst. Making sure the screenshot shows enough, uploading everything and adding tags can take half an hour or so, especially when you‚Äôre doing a few images at a time. This isn‚Äôt a reflection on either site‚Äôs experience, they‚Äôre both very easy to use, but if you‚Äôre trying to add a useful description to your post it can take a pretty long time which brings me to… *

It‚Äôs hard to provide context

The users viewing, liking and commenting on your images haven‚Äôt seen the brief, the communication between you and the client or tried other ideas out already. A small description isn‚Äôt really enough to give much context so a lot of the opinions you‚Äôll get on your work is little more than ‚Äúthat‚Äôs pretty‚Äù or ‚Äúthat‚Äôs ugly‚Äù. *

Subjective and unhelpful opinions

Somebody saying ‚Äúthat‚Äôs great‚Äù is all very lovely and ego-soothing, but doesn‚Äôt have much depth. An overall positive response is definitely better than negative, but without reasons and justifications in comments, it‚Äôs not going to help you better your work.

The conclusion

I think the benefits and negatives above apply to the overall usage of Dribbble and Forrst. It‚Äôs great for popularity contests and making yourself feel big and clever, but helpful feedback is often rare (especially if you don‚Äôt ask for it!)

I‚Äôd like to try using Dribbble and Forrst for feedback on a longer-term project. I can imagine they‚Äôre potentially useful for the in-house designers of web apps, creating a buzz around teaser shots and getting feedback on visual elements, especially if they‚Äôre used regularly.

By the way, if anybody could give me guidance on the proper pronunciation of ‚ÄòForrst‚Äô, I‚Äôd really appreciate it. I can‚Äôt say it aloud without sounding ridiculous.
