item.title: dConstruct 2010
item.description:
I was a bit skeptical about dConstruct at first. The idea of a conference based on ‚Äòcreativity and ideas‚Äô made me worry it might be a bit pretentious but I was convinced by a lot of friends on Twitter that it‚Äôd be worthwhile, and they were so right.

I went with a notebook and an open mind. I didn‚Äôt want to go all reverse-snob on the pretentious (something I‚Äôm generally pretty guilty of being) and be ignorant of learning when I‚Äôd paid ¬£¬£s for the pleasure.

And I ended up writing reams. Well, seven sides of a scruffy notebook, so here are the best bits I remember from each talk for the benefit of my friends who couldn‚Äôt be there.

Summaries

I‚Äôve tried to summarise the main ideas from the talks. If I totally missed the point or didn‚Äôt do it justice, I‚Äôm really sorry!

Marty Neumeier ‚Äî The Designful Company

Branding is about how the consumer feels about your product. To differentiate your brand from others, you must be good and different.

Brendan Dawes ‚Äî Boil, Simmer, Reduce

Collect as much inspiration and information as possible, consider it all and the reduce it down until there‚Äôs nothing left to take away.

David McCandless ‚Äî Information Is Beautiful

Infographics can be used to help us understand and relate to the huge amount of information and data we‚Äôre drowning in.

Samantha Warren ‚Äî The Power and Beauty of Typography

Letters can say more than the words they spell. Picking fonts for a project is like picking shoes for an outfit, you must pick the most contextually appropriate font.

John Gruber ‚Äî The Auteur Theory Of Design

Much like in film production, collaborative web projects can benefit from an auteur who acts as an arbiter of taste and strives for high quality.

Hannah Donovan ‚Äî Jam Session: What Improvisation Can Teach Us About Design

We can learn about improvisation in design from improvisation in music. Making sure tools don‚Äôt get in the way, we have a structure to follow and roles to keep, to help us free our self-expression.

James Bridle ‚Äî The Value Of Ruins

We need to make sure information is being kept, given history, value and versions to help us understand its context, the world and protect the information from cultural destruction.

Tom Coates ‚Äî Everything The Network Touches

The future is in the connectivity of data, up to huge scales such a cities

Merlin Mann ‚Äî Kerning, Orgasms & Those Goddamned Japanese Toothpicks

Nerd are cool because they really care about something. It‚Äôs great to be a nerd because you suck up huge quantities of information. It‚Äôs important to ensure you keep the information up-to-date and relevant.

Various points and ideas

I‚Äôve tried to capture some of the ideas from my notes in this mind map thing, in addition/support to the summaries. If you can read my writing, you might find it interesting. I just did it to help cement the ideas in my head as I‚Äôm one of those people who has to write something down a million times to get it to stick.

(You might want to view it full-size to attempt to read the text.)

Overall conference thoughts

The more people I know, the better conferences always are. It can be pretty hard to get chatting to somebody you don‚Äôt know in a room full of people who are stereotypically shy (especially when you‚Äôre in a minority of girls and so stick out like a sore thumb!)

I loved Brighton as a destination (pretty easy travel for me) and the venue was very smart. It was a bit tricky to write notes in the darker parts of the theatre but wouldn‚Äôt be so hard on back-lit devices (I opted for paper as I‚Äôm still really slow on iPad.) It would have been great to charge my iPhone/iPad during the talks as most of my break times were spent out of the venue trying to find non-coffee/tea refreshments.

What I noticed in particular was that there weren‚Äôt any questions at the end of the talks. In a way this was good because it prevented the awkward silence that is often heralded with ‚ÄòAny questions?‚Äô at other conferences. However, it did give you the feeling of one-way communication. Much more like being at a lecture than being in a lesson.

It was good to see speakers I hadn‚Äôt seen before too. I think I‚Äôd already seen a variation of Brendan Dawes‚Äô talk at Future Of Web Design, but otherwise the talks and speakers were totally new to me. This was refreshing over some of the conference veterans, because how much do you practice what you preach when you spend your whole time touring a talk?!

item.title: Me vs We
item.description:
There‚Äôs something that‚Äôs been niggling at me for ages. The way people act as if they‚Äôre a multi-person company when they‚Äôre really just one individual. This whole ‚Äòwe‚Äô syndrome.

We have a great new client now working with us at Just Little Old Me Ltd.

Sometimes it makes me giggle when I know somebody is an individual ‚Äòme‚Äô and they‚Äôre saying ‚Äòwe‚Äô as if they‚Äôre some kind of medieval queen. I just can‚Äôt help feeling it‚Äôs a little bit deceptive to act in this way.

Why bother?

I can see there‚Äôs a couple of reasons why people feel the need to pretend to be bigger than they really are:

  1. It makes them look big and official to others, making them look more trustworthy. That company won‚Äôt run away with my money, but that single cowboy there might do.
  2. It seems to give them some kind of prestige over that teenage kid working in his bedroom. Oh, it‚Äôs not just a student, they‚Äôre a proper company.

But really, why do we do this?

The web is still young, and it‚Äôs incredibly difficult to tell the hardworking souls from the shady characters. If most of your communication is web-based, without meeting face-to-face or even speaking on the phone, it‚Äôs hard for a client to pick up on those gut instincts and little signs that tells you somebody can‚Äôt be trusted.

We‚Äôve come to inherently trust bigger companies. People will eat in a chain restaurant because they know what to expect. Companies made up of multiple people appear to be more stable because there‚Äôs more people to get the work done.

I can understand why it looks good to be big company.

It‚Äôs just being deceptive

What I really don‚Äôt understand about people who create this fa√ßade of a multiple person company is that they‚Äôre losing all the benefits of appearing to be trustworthy and stable. If you‚Äôre lying (however well-intended that lie is,) you‚Äôre no-longer credible. I have an immediate distrust of anybody who claims who says ‚Äòwe‚Äô when they‚Äôre really just a ‚Äòme‚Äô as I wonder what other truths they‚Äôre bending.

Saying ‚Äòwe‚Äô and talking as a company and not an individual also makes you seem detached. Is your company persona all that different from your individual persona? If it is, then why? Why do you have to pretend to be a different person to do business?

It‚Äôs really not all that bad being a ‚Äòme‚Äô

I‚Äôm Laura Kalbag, I‚Äôm a sole trader and my company is called ‚ÄòLaura Kalbag‚Äô. What you see really is what you get. Sometimes I sense a lack of trust in me because I‚Äôm not an agency or a big company. You know what, I don‚Äôt care. I‚Äôd rather not work with somebody who suspects I might not be reliable. If we‚Äôre starting out with some big fat negative preconceptions, it‚Äôs going to be harder to get positive feelings from that person.

As an individual, people can be assured that:

  • I‚Äôm the one doing all the work. They will talk to me and I will execute the designs, development etc all based on our direct conversation. There‚Äôs less room for misinterpretation if there‚Äôs only one link in the chain.
  • I‚Äôm as vulnerable as them. Weakness isn‚Äôt always negative. I‚Äôve got to directly make money to have food and shelter, so have my clients. It‚Äôs much more personal when you‚Äôre not throwing somebody else‚Äôs money around.
  • I don‚Äôt have to check that what I‚Äôm saying is the right thing on behalf of my company and/or employer. Ditch all the legalese, I‚Äôm talking to you man-to-man (or girl-to-man or girl-to-girl, you see what I mean!)

I feel like I‚Äôm good enough

There‚Äôs upsides and downsides to hiring a freelancer or an agency but the important thing is that I‚Äôm happy with what I am. If you‚Äôve got no confidence in yourself as an individual freelancer, then go find yourself some like-minds and form an agency!

It‚Äôs not arrogance to say I feel like I‚Äôm good enough to speak as myself. I‚Äôve got as many insecurities as the next person but I enjoy being a human, friendly face in a sea of (often) faceless companies.

So next time you‚Äôre thinking of saying ‚Äòwe‚Äô when you just mean ‚Äòme‚Äô, think about how much that little word means. I think it‚Äôd be better if everybody was a little bit more honest.

Therefore, going to a company and stating that ‚Äòwe‚Äô can accomplish something, even though that company only has one employee, is accurate; they become a ‚Äòwe‚Äô as and when needed. I know you‚Äôre not necessarily pointing the finger at these type of companies, but they are often the ones who you‚Äôll find out later are a ‚Äòme‚Äô but call themselves a ‚Äòwe‚Äô. I AM a student, and i am running a business, but i‚Äôve been doing both for the past 5 years, all my customers are aware of that and none of them have a problem with it… So yes, maybe I should put ‚ÄòI‚Äô, but a lot of the things I offer, i personally do not do.. Would it be wrong to refer to the web designer's company as a 'me' in a tender? It certainly would not be a 'me' who completed the work. (with same quality) ‚Äì; You can outsource to speed up production in order to meet deadline. (bcs you are late since you are dead busy but don't want to pay penalties)

item.title: Year One
item.description:
It‚Äôs been a whole year since I officially started working as a freelance designer last August.¬†I graduated from uni, had a brief fling with some full-time remote working, had an awkward interview with a recruiter and then decided that I‚Äôd rather give it a go by myself.

Getting Started

I felt pretty ready for freelancing full-time, I‚Äôd had a lot of experience on projects whilst I was at university. I knew I could run a project and I knew I could do the work. I‚Äôd done a one-day course at uni in freelance accounting and got myself a business account and subscription to FreeAgent so I felt like I could stay on top of the finance side.

The first month started pretty slowly, but that was only the first month. With the help of two lovely people in particular, Chris Book and Simon Wheatley, I got to know a few people and started getting a few projects under my belt. I really couldn‚Äôt thank these two guys enough for recommending me to their friends and giving me great opportunities.

I‚Äôve found that meeting people (I don‚Äôt like networking, it‚Äôs too false) is incredibly important when you‚Äôre starting out. After that, my network seemed to grow itself!

The Stats

I can‚Äôt believe how much I‚Äôve done. I‚Äôve just worked these out:

  • Projects completed ‚Äì; 27
  • Current projects ‚Äì; 6
  • WordPress themes created ‚Äì; 13
  • Logos designed ‚Äì; 10
  • iPhone app designs ‚Äì; 3
  • Static website designs ‚Äì; 6
  • Illustration projects ‚Äì; 2
  • Website maintenance projects ‚Äì; 3
  • HTML e-mail designs ‚Äì; 1

Getting Work

From the stats above, you can see that I‚Äôve been busy! Thanks to Chris and Simon and a lot of really great clients, I‚Äôve managed to be constantly booked up and busy since last October. I‚Äôm now booking up around two/three months in advance.

It‚Äôs been difficult. Learning to not stress and cope with a big workload is one of the many things I‚Äôve tried to get my head around.

Trying to learn

Not necessarily things I‚Äôve already learnt, but things I‚Äôm in the process of learning!

  1. ### Scheduling projects is all well and good but nothing ever stays on schedule.

Feedback isn‚Äôt instant, work takes much longer or nowhere near as long as estimated. It‚Äôs not a nightmare if I don‚Äôt stress about it, but I‚Äôm getting good at frequently reorganising and juggling projects.

  1. ### Desk space is important.

Work got miles easier when I had my own working area set up. Matt built me a great custom desk, shelf unit and wall-mounted my second screen. When I‚Äôm at my desk, I‚Äôm working. The division between working at home and just being at home makes a big difference.

My desk area (if anybody knows a good way to keep those cables tidy, I‚Äôd love to hear it!!)

  1. ### Honesty, friendliness and manners go a long way.

Sometimes I‚Äôm horrified by e-mails I receive. I take time to write e-mails, try to be polite and I‚Äôm always honest, even if it means admitting I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm doing. I really appreciate it when people are open with me, and it seems to work the other way for me too!

  1. ### Don‚Äôt take on too much work. Don‚Äôt work when you‚Äôre ill. Just don‚Äôt overwork at all.

Nothing kills the desire to work than overworking. At first I was happy to work 10+ hour days. Then I was constantly tired and resentful. Now I take plenty of time to relax and always take time off when I‚Äôm ill. I‚Äôm so much more productive and enthusiastic for being happy.

  1. ### Clients take you much more seriously when you charge

When you‚Äôre working on ‚Äòportfolio projects‚Äô or ‚Äògetting experience‚Äô when you‚Äôre starting out it‚Äôs very easy to find people who want a lot of your time for nothing. It‚Äôs not their fault but these clients will expect you to always do a lot for nothing, and they‚Äôll never understand the value of your work because you‚Äôve placed no value on it in the first place.

I found that as soon as I started charging reasonable rates, I got reasonable clients. Not really an issue I had over the last year, but one I had to get over to start working professionally!

  1. ### The busier you are, the more they want you

It‚Äôs very strange, the busier I get the more clients are willing to wait to work with me. I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs that by telling a potential client that you already have clients reassures them that somebody else wants to work with you, so you must be decent enough.

The One Downside

I don‚Äôt have work mates. Well, I have one and that‚Äôs my lovely man,¬†Matt. Matt mostly works from home too so it‚Äôs lucky we don‚Äôt get sick of each other. However, living in Reigate (not exactly the hippest tech town around) and working from home, I miss hanging out with people who have the same work interests as me.

Going to Future of Web Apps, Future of Web Design and openMIC are like going on a social binge, I‚Äôm totally exhausted afterwards and probably babble incoherently at everybody when I‚Äôm there. Twitter and Skype are both useful in their own ways but it‚Äôs not the same.

Hopefully there‚Äôs more years to come

I‚Äôm hoping this is the beginning of something good. It‚Äôd be hard to give up on the luxury of working flexibly from home. I‚Äôm making enough to live on and I‚Äôm having fun at the same time. I really hope this post might give confidence to some people who are thinking about leaping into freelance. It‚Äôs hard work but it‚Äôs the best work I‚Äôve ever done.

item.title: Girlguides UK Anti-airbrushing Campaign
item.description:
I don‚Äôt like to say it, but I think the Girlguides UK campaign (#gukforrealimages) call for labelling all airbrushed images of women is unrealistic.

Our¬†girls and young women are demanding action from the Prime Minister to introduce compulsory labelling to distinguish between airbrushed and natural imagesin order to ‚Äòshape a generation of self-confident girls and young women.

(Tell us the truth ‚Äì; Girls call for honesty over airbrushing.¬†Girlguiding website)

I‚Äôm a girl, and I‚Äôve had all the usual confidence issues growing up that are no doubt in-part created by the unhealthy portrayal of women in the media. Many girls (and boys) would certainly benefit from there being more natural body shapes being shown in advertising and the media in general. If it‚Äôs going to be aspirational, then it should give people aspirations of realistic, achievable goals.

However, I‚Äôm not sure that the lines between air brushing (by which I assume they mean altering the appearance of a model) and post-production are clear enough. I think it is probably near-impossible to find a commercial image out there that hasn‚Äôt had some kind of post-production applied. It could be anything from changing the colouring and exposure all the way to placing a model into an artificial environment. In post production the artist is designing the image to suit the advertising campaign in every possible way, this will inevitably mean changes from the very raw basic image shot in a studio. If all the images used in commercial campaigns looked like our holiday snaps, they wouldn‚Äôt have the desired effect. Commercial campaigns are designed to make us want to be like the people in the photos, be it richer, slimmer or just happier.

There‚Äôs already been labelling in TV ads. All the mascara advertisements now have a ‚Äòenhanced in post production‚Äô label at some point. It‚Äôs obvious that nobody could get eyelashes a mile long with a plain old high street mascara so it‚Äôs false advertising. Does this labelling work? Do children understand what post production is? Does everybody read the small text on TV adverts? I don‚Äôt really think so. It just means nobody‚Äôs going to sue the cosmetics companies.

How do the Girlguides propose these images should be labelled? If there‚Äôs an image where nothing has been done except the smoothing of a girl‚Äôs skin and applying some extra eye makeup, how is that distinguished by a label from an image where they‚Äôve given her somebody else‚Äôs breasts, trimmed her waist by six inches, changed the colour of her hair, the colour of her skin and lengthened her eyelashes. Does each image then have to come with a list of everything the digital artist did to perfect the photo? I‚Äôd imagine on most campaigns there‚Äôd be more label than photo!

Where then do they draw the line at what needs to be labelled? TV adverts, magazines, billboards, clothes catalogues so also clothes store websites, packaging, DVD, CD and book covers. You can see where I‚Äôm going with this‚Ä¶

Rather than going guns blazing into a campaign to label as many commercial images as possible ‚Äòfake‚Äô, I think it would be far more productive to try to tackle these problems at the root. Why do we aspire to be ridiculously thin? Who are the role models that make us this way? Can we change the attitudes of the influencers, the magazines and advertisers that insist on these bizarre body images being what we should aspire to?

I think it‚Äôs great that the Girlguides are drawing attention to these issues but there‚Äôs much more to them than dodgy photos and a bit of small print to fix the perceptions of young girls.

item.title: How the iPad is saving my sanity
item.description:
Fan girl

I‚Äôve had an iPad since the day it was released in the UK. I bought it because I‚Äôm a fan girl. I admit it. I could pretend that I wanted it to take to conferences or use for testing or when I didn‚Äôt need a laptop when I went to visit clients. In truth, I only go to one or two conferences per year, I‚Äôve not yet made a site that needed an iPad-specific site and when I go to visit clients I always need my laptop. I was simply justifying my desire to have something shiny.

When my iPad arrived I was in love with the glossy screen, the simple gestures and the idea of all the tasks I could now complete without using my laptop. Thing is, it doesn‚Äôt run Photoshop or Coda or any of the apps I actually need for working. It may suit other people who just need a word processor, spreadsheet or presentation software, but when it comes to specialist tools the iPad isn‚Äôt the device.

Workaholic

Yet more and more I‚Äôm finding that the iPad is stopping me from going mad. Being a freelancer that works from home, it‚Äôs very difficult to switch off. I often have days where I sit at my desk til six, then just move my laptop to the TV and carry on working until it‚Äôs time to sleep. This is a really bad habit and just leads to all-work-and-no-play and a big fat stress-face. Many wise people talk about keeping normal office hours and being equally productive and there‚Äôs a lot of truth in that.

Now I leave my laptop when I‚Äôm finished working, turn it off and engage iPad. I can‚Äôt work with the iPad, so I won‚Äôt. I can read e-mails, but if I reply from my iPad I won‚Äôt have a record of the reply on my laptop for reference (so I rarely do that.) I can visit as many websites as I like, but I won‚Äôt be writing any HTML or CSS. I can sketch and doodle ideas and even make brainstorms but I won‚Äôt be creating any graphics.

The result is a total separation of work and play. The iPad fulfils all my casual browsing needs and I‚Äôm a more sociable and less stressed being.

Playtime

There‚Äôs added bonuses to this too. There are plenty of cool apps on the iPad to keep me entertained.

iBooks

A couple of weeks ago I read my first full book (albeit a reasonably short 200-page one) using iBooks. To all those saying it doesn‚Äôt beat a real book, I say stop being so old-fashioned. If you‚Äôre used to staring at a screen for 12 hours a day, your eyes won‚Äôt particularly complain. I set the settings to large-ish text, changed the colouring to sepia and turned the brightness down. My eyes were very happy.

The books are a little bit pricey, being a few pounds more than their paperback friends, and there‚Äôs certainly not everything in the store. It‚Äôs not much of a problem for me as I rarely have time to read more than a couple of paperbacks a year (though I see that changing with iBooks) and a boyfriend who is being driven mad by the quantity of books I insist on keeping.

Reeder

RSS feeds are no longer a case of me fighting a losing battle. Reeder is a beautiful feed reader and now I love spending spare time catching up on feeds without stressing about reading them when I‚Äôm at my desk.

Reeder also gives you loads of ways to make use of the articles you read so they‚Äôre not just lost in the ether of my bad memory. I‚Äôm a serial Delicious user so I can tag and save the useful bookmarks straight into Delicious. I also use Instapaper Read It Later (Instapaper on iPad just doesn‚Äôt feel right) so I can save the longer read-it-later articles to there. If I want to add a cool image to Zootool, I just open the link in Safari and lasso it from the browser.

WordPress

So now I‚Äôm typing this on WordPress for iPad. It‚Äôs perfect for those wifi-less moments when you can‚Äôt access your WordPress admin. You can have drafts that are just local to your iPad or sync your drafts across to the web. It‚Äôs a fairly minimal interface, relying on HTML if you want to include any kind of formatting, and you can only attach images at the end of a post.

However, if you‚Äôre like me and tap away at a few blog posts at once, dipping in to edit them every now and again, WordPress for iPad is great for a distraction-free environment.

Twitterrific

Many people would agree that Tweetie is the most native-style mac Twitter client. I used Twitterrific for mac before I was a Tweetie fan and it just feels too Adobe-Airy. It doesn‚Äôt feel native, it doesn‚Äôt quite look right, there‚Äôs something a bit flimsy about it.

But Twitterrific on iPad is a revelation. Landscape mode is totally where it‚Äôs at, it has the extra column/menu down the left hand side. Easy to browse, packed full of features (maybe not so many as Twitter for iPhone or the so-ugly-I-seriously-can‚Äôt-stand-it Tweetdeck) but for a casual addict it feels just right.

When you‚Äôre writing a tweet or replying you get a lovely huge box to work within. A particularly cool feature is that it shows the tweet you‚Äôre replying to as well for reference.

The little popup boxes are great too, you can instantly access all the relevant details about a person including their recent tweets from a few taps.

CropSuey

It‚Äôs pretty disappointing that there‚Äôs no iPhoto or iMovie style tools for iPad. Alongside a cheap way to import your photos (I haven‚Äôt tried the official camera to iPad cable yet,) it feels like a missed opportunity. The iPad is great for viewing photos you‚Äôve transferred from iPhoto on the mac, but that‚Äôs about it.

When I started writing blog posts on my iPad, and taking screenshots into the Photos (the only way to directly get images into Photos on the iPad?!) I needed to rotate and crop the images so they looked right on my blog.

I did a bit of searching on the App Store and came across Crop Suey HD. This app is simple but does exactly what it says and with incredibly intuitive tools. With straighten, rotate, flip and crop you can easily get your images looking much neater and save them back into the library for use with other apps.

Finding Apps

The downside to the iPad is app discoverability. Despite Apple selling so many devices, there don‚Äôt seem to be many iPads around. People aren‚Äôt constantly talking about new iPad apps on Twitter like they do with iPhone apps. There‚Äôs very rarely that word-of-mouth way to happen across a cool app.

So you have to rely on the App Store. Unless you‚Äôre after a top 10 app, or a random Staff Pick that‚Äôs been sitting there for a month, you just have to search and hope. You can wade through pages and pages of mediocre apps in the Categories trying to find that rare gem. It‚Äôs incredibly difficult to be paired up with something you‚Äôll like, use, and will be worth the relatively high cost of often ¬£5.99+.

Appsfire‚Äôs App Stream is trying to solve the discoverability problem. A stream of small app icons rotate around the board. You can tap them to see more, basically all the info you get in the app store. If you like it, you can tap again to view and purchase on the App Store.

Unfortunately this really relies on you judging a book by its cover. The slickest, prettiest icons are most likely to catch your attention and you‚Äôre most likely to assume the apps with duff icons are going to have a rubbish app design. Whilst it‚Äôs pretty likely, I feel like this random stream of icons is as bad as trying to filter through App Store listings. It‚Äôs a bit faster to load, but you‚Äôre not even getting any contextual category or ranking information.

As the Apple app stores get huger, there‚Äôs going to be a much greater need for discovering the best apps for the individual. I can imagine there‚Äôs a lot more startups getting into these areas and I‚Äôd love to hear if anybody out there has any recommendations for me! I want to get even more out of my iPad time!

item.title: WordPress 3.0 Part 3‚ÄîTheme Development and the Design
item.description:
This post has three parts. This is part three. Visit the other parts below:

  • Part 1:¬†WordPress 3.0‚ÄîPre 3.0 and Beyond
  • Part 2: WordPress 3.0‚ÄîReally WordPress 3.0

Easier for theme developers to make it easy for users

The following WordPress 3.0 features really make it easier for the big-time theme developers who create highly customisable themes.

Menus

This is brilliant. Before the menus feature, we had to bodge any extra links we wanted on to the end of the wp_list_pages (that just lists pages!) function without much control on what was shown, and only being able to adjust the orders of the pages by entering a number into a clunky text box.

Now you can easily create drag-and-drop menus with custom links place anywhere within the navigation. This enables users to:

  • Nest pages and links that don‚Äôt already have parent-child relationships in the Page hierarchy.
  • Use different names for the pages in the navigation (handy if you want to call the ‚ÄòAbout‚Äô page ‚ÄòHome‚Äô in the navigation.
  • Link to pages on totally different websites.

All these functions are perfect for users who don‚Äôt want to get their hands dirty in the PHP files and make it easier for theme developers as they just need to add the menu function to their functions.php file and use the right template tag to include the customised menus in their themes.

add_action( 'init', 'register_my_menu' ); function register_my_menu() { register_nav_menu( 'navigation-menu', __( 'Navigation Menu' ) ); }

Add this to the functions.php file to register a menu by the name of ‚ÄòNavigation Menu‚Äô

<?php wp_nav_menu( array( 'theme_location' => 'navigation-menu' ) ); ?>

Add this to the template file wherever you want to include the menu.

Custom backgrounds and headers

For theme creators making themes for a wide user base, custom backgrounds and headers are very useful. Most of the big name theme producers have offered custom backgrounds and headers as part of their ultra-sexy, ultra-customisable themes for a long time but now the smaller scale theme developers can do this by adding some extra functions to their functions.php file and into the relevant template files.

I haven‚Äôt tried creating a theme with these features yet, as I tend to give my clients one custom-created choice as part of the web design, but you can see custom backgrounds and headers in action in the new default theme, TwentyTen, which I use on this blog. You should be able to see that big yellow block at the top of the page. This is a custom header image I created and uploaded using the settings under Appearance > Header.

As you can see from my image below, it‚Äôs incredibly easy to upload your own header or you can pick from one of the beautiful photographs taken by Matt Mullenweg, the creator of WordPress.

If you want to know more about using custom backgrounds and headers, I‚Äôd recommend taking a look at the reasonably well-commented code in the TwentyTen theme. Unfortunately I haven‚Äôt got any other recommended bookmarks for this yet, I hope you‚Äôll forgive me!

Change in design

TwentyTen

WordPress 3.0 also comes with a cool new default theme called TwentyTen. It was getting to the point where no decent blog would be seen dead in the old WordPress default theme, so it was definitely in need of change.

TwentyTen is clean and simple (and the theme I use on my blog) and takes advantage of the custom backgrounds, headers and menus to make it easy to change the look and feel without having to get into the CSS.

If you want to try TwentyTen out, you can find it in the WordPress theme repository and through the Themes > ‚ÄòInstall‚Äô section in your WordPress admin by searching ‚Äòtwentyten‚Äô.

WordPress admin realign

If you follow me on Twitter, you might have heard me whining a bit about the new WordPress admin realign. I‚Äôll call it a realign as they‚Äôve only made some changes, not redesigned the lot.

The idea behind these changes is that it brings the content into focus, and it is more legible to read dark text on a light background so it makes the WordPress admin, which is now entirely dark on light, more accessible.

I have the utmost respect for those working on the WordPress admin interface, and have briefly discussed the decisions with John O‚ÄôNolan, member of the Core WordPress UI Team, on Twitter. I appreciate their reasons behind the changes and that it must be very difficult to please everybody in these scenarios. (Here comes the but)

But I find the new admin harder to use, and I don‚Äôt believe it is out of a lack of familiarity. Here are my reasons:

  1. #### There is a general lack of contrast across all the admin

It is all dark grey against white and light grey backgrounds separated by light grey border lines. My eye isn‚Äôt drawn to any different elements anymore, it doesn‚Äôt suggest so strongly where I am or where I should go first. I‚Äôm an idiot and need to be led!

  1. #### When you select the title text box when creating a new post, the label for the text box disappears

If you have cognitive issues, I can‚Äôt see how this is accessible. Chances are, you‚Äôll select that first input box available and then be clueless about what that box is for. The label-in-an-input-box isn‚Äôt yet a strong-enough standard to make it obvious that you need to deselect the text input. It‚Äôs more of a consistent pattern for search input boxes, where the function is made obvious by the accompanying presence of a ‚ÄòSearch‚Äô button.

  1. #### I find dark grey a really peculiar choice of colour for an alert

This little alert that lets you know if you have comments, or need to update your plugins or WordPress installation, used to be orange. Orange stood out against the mostly white/grey/blue colour scheme and was clearly there to be noticed. Orange signifies something to be aware about, not quite red being something dangerous but not green for ‚Äòeverything is fine‚Äô. Even though this new alert style is a reversible of the dark-on-light text shown everywhere else, I think it‚Äôs a very unusual choice to have something less colourful for an alert.

To be fair these changes haven‚Äôt made the admin unusable. I am being picky. It would be very difficult to undo all the great work of Jane Wells and the UI team since WordPress 2.7.

item.title: WordPress 3.0 Part 2‚ÄîReally WordPress 3.0
item.description:
This post has three parts. This is part two. Visit the other parts below:

  • Part 1: WordPress 3.0‚ÄîPre 3.0 and Beyond
  • Part 3: WordPress 3.0‚ÄîTheme Development and the Design

Really WordPress 3.0

Custom Post Types

Custom Post Types are my new best friends. I have used new post types on every client project since the beta of WordPress 3.0. That‚Äôs how valuable I think they are.

For any content that you need to act like a post, but not actually be a post, custom post types are there for you. If you already have a news section that uses posts, but also want an articles section separate from your posts, custom post types are what you need.

One of my latest site designs, stuartclayton.com, I used no fewer than four different custom post types:

  1. #### Discography

It‚Äôs pretty self-explanatory, I used the custom post types to list a new CD in each post.

  1. #### Books

Each one of Stuart‚Äôs books has its own post in the ‚ÄòBooks‚Äô post type.

  1. #### Features

This is a bit less obvious. In the sidebar or footer on every page is a feature that shows a latest book, video or audio track.

For this I used a custom post type of ‚ÄòFeature‚Äô with a featured image to show the image and using the title and text content (even though it‚Äôs very little text) as standard. The ‚ÄòBuy Now‚Äô button is created by entering a URL and button text into a custom write panel (also known as meta boxes.)

  1. #### Gear

The gear is pretty special as I made use of a ‚ÄòGear‚Äô custom post type with a ‚ÄòType of gear‚Äô custom taxonomy. You certainly couldn‚Äôt do that a few versions ago!

Each item of musical gear that Stuart has is (or will be) listed under the ‚ÄòGear‚Äô section. Then to group the different gear by whether it‚Äôs a bass, an amp, strings or effects, a category-style custom taxonomy is used. This helps dictate how the pages are laid out.

I struggled a bit with custom post types at first. I think it¬†It was probably because the developers hadn‚Äôt quite ironed out all the quirks and I was too keen on trying out everything during the beta. I could create custom post types that showed up in the admin with no problem, but had issues with choosing which features showed in the editors.

If you, like me, get a bit confused with the huge amount of options for custom post types in the functions.php file, I really would recommend you give Custom Post Type UI by WebDevStudios a go. This excellent plugin does just what you would do in your functions.php file but gives it a friendly checkbox and text input interface in your WordPress admin so you needn‚Äôt write any code.

For those that more confident, these are the best resources I‚Äôve found on creating custom post types straight into your themes (or plugins):

  • Custom Post Types in WordPress by Justin Tadlock (I know, I‚Äôm a fan!)
  • Custom Post Types on the WordPress Codex
  • How to add a custom icon to your custom post type by Ptah Dunbar

loop.php and other Template Parts

A change in WordPress 3.0 that I‚Äôm a bit confused about is the template parts, which separates the WordPress loop into its own file, loop.php. It is certainly not necessary to do this in order¬†to make your WordPress theme work, and the idea behind doing this is that you can now easily separate repeatable parts of your templates into different files and call them when you need them, thus preventing you repeating yourself many times in one file and needing to edit the same repeated line of code multiple times just because you want to change a few characters.

However, the implementation of this in the new default TwentyTen theme seems to contradict this non-repetitive, breaking up into digestible chunks, sensibility. Apologies for the huge amount of code that follows:

If you wade through the code above, you might notice that the loop is cycling through special displays for a gallery category, an asides category, the archives and search, and then all other posts.

This seems utterly bizarre to me. Why, in an exercise that is aimed at splitting the code into manageable chunks are they lumping all of these different outputs into one new file? According to the [Template Hierarchy](http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Hierarchy#Category_display), you could have separate template files for

* a category named ‚Äògallery‚Äô (category-gallery.php)
* a category named ‚Äòasides‚Äô (category-asides.php)
* an archive page (archive.php)
* and search results (search.php.)

Leaving all other posts happily served by index.php. This would keep your templates separate and easy to read as well as stopping WordPress having to cycle through all of those conditional options by just hitting the relevant template first.

As I‚Äôve said before, I‚Äôm no PHP developer, but if somebody could explain the logic of this particular loop.php file to me, it‚Äôd make me feel a lot happier!

item.title: WordPress 3.0 Part 1‚ÄîPre 3.0 and Beyond
item.description:
This post has three parts. This is part one. Visit the other parts below:

  • Part 2: WordPress 3.0‚ÄîReally WordPress 3.0
  • Part 3: WordPress 3.0‚ÄîTheme Development and the Design

I‚Äôm a big fat WordPress fan. I love the people behind it, I love the ethicsand I love how it makes it easy for me to make cool sites that my clients can update themselves.

Not really being much of a PHP developer, I can still get by and can make fairly capable themes from-scratch for my clients. However, it was getting to the point where I couldn‚Äôt offer clients an easy way to input content that wasn‚Äôt a standard page or a standard blog post without getting a bit hacky with posts, categories and tags.

These solutions were OK, but really far too much of a workaround for clients who were only fairly basic computer users in the first.

Then along came the wondrous‚Ä¶

WordPress 3.0

Actually, it started a bit before that with WordPress 2.9 with the infinitely useful post thumbnails.

Featured Images

But I‚Äôll carry on by calling ‚Äòpost thumbnails‚Äô by their new name, ‚Äòfeatured images‚Äô, as this is what they‚Äôve become known as since WordPress 3.0.

Featured images were a selling point in many magazine-style themes for a long time. The ability to have an image that was a visual representation of a post was incredibly sought-after, especially if those images could also be shown in some kind of javascript carousel that rotated the images on the front page of the site.¬†As a result, a huge amount of post-image carousel-type themes exist using all kinds of hacky ways to select a post‚Äôs image as the ‚Äòfeatured‚Äô one.

I used the excellent Get The Image plugin by (the equally excellent) Justin Tadlock when I wanted to use a featured image in a theme. Get The Image cycled through images linked to your post through custom fields, then through the attachments to the post, and even setting a default image, making it really easy to implement featured images in a way that all clients could understand. I still would recommend Get The Image if you want to pick images straight from your posts, rather than setting a specific featured image.

However, setting a specific featured image couldn‚Äôt be easier, and I see very few occasions where it wouldn‚Äôt be perfect for the job.

First, you‚Äôll need to enable featured images in your functions.php file. This prevents a ‚ÄòFeatured Image‚Äô box appearing in themes which don‚Äôt support the use of featured images (which could cause a lot of confusion for users.) All this requires is a little:

add_theme_support( ‘post-thumbnails’ );
Then you can see the Featured Image box appear in your post and page editors.

The image selection process is identical to that of adding standard images into the post. You can choose to select from your computer, from a URL or from the Media Library. All you need to make sure is that, instead of hitting the ‚ÄòInsert into Post‚Äô button, you select ‚ÄòUse as featured image‚Äô.

If you only want to allow Featured Images for posts in your theme, you can specify this through:

add_theme_support( ‘post-thumbnails’, array( ‘post’ ) );
Or for just pages:

add_theme_support( ‘post-thumbnails’, array( ‘page’ ) );
Then when it comes to including the Featured Image in your theme, you‚Äôll just need to include:

<?php the_post_thumbnail(); ?>
Really nice and simple!

Even better, you can have more fine-grained control over the sizes of the images, and have different types of image sizes through a few more lines in your functions.php file:

set_post_thumbnail_size( 100, 100, true );
// Set the standard size for your featured images
add_image_size( ‘magazine-column-image’, 400, 300 );
//Specify a custom image size, you can do this as many
times as you want
This is great if you want to output small thumbnail images on your homepage template and large feature images on your article pages.

For more depth on featured images I recommend you read Mark Jaquith‚Äôs pro writeup New in WordPress 2.9: Post Thumbnail images.

Custom Taxonomies

As early as WordPress 2.8 also came custom taxonomies, a sneak peek into something beyond bloggy categories and bloggy tags. For those who blog on specialist subjects you can do without categories and have different hierarchical taxonomies (category trees to people like me), such as ‚Äògenres‚Äô for your film reviews.

If you wanted to tag your film reviews with different actors names, but still keep standard tags to describe your review, you can do this. If you still wanted to organise your fashion blog by different types of articles, using categories, but also wanted to choose from a list of ¬†items of clothes to describe your article, you can do this as well.

These are a bit trickier to implement than post thumbnails. Not much, but there‚Äôs a bit more to explain in the functions.php file, so if you want to know more I‚Äôd recommend that you visit one (or all) of the fantastic resources that I use, below:

1.Custom Taxonomies on the WordPress Codex 2. Custom Taxonomies in WordPress 2.8 by Justin Tadlock 3. Creating a page template that lists all your custom taxonomies by Justin Tadlock 4. Introducing WordPress 3 Custom Taxonomies on NetTuts

item.title: HTML5 For Web Designers
item.description:
Even though the specification for HTML5 isn‚Äôt yet complete, those of us who are a bit eager to get into it now have the perfect book to get us started.

HTML5 For Web Designers by Jeremy Keith is the first offering from A Book Apart. It‚Äôs a very easy read, not an endless reference, which took me a couple of hours to fully digest whilst I was enjoying the sun. They‚Äôve been some of the first people to produce a book about HTML5 and they prove it isn‚Äôt too early to start discussing the new specification and its impact on the web.

The book is split into six chapters:

  1. A Brief History of Markup
  2. The Design of HTML5
  3. Rich Media
  4. Web Forms 2.0
  5. Semantics
  6. Using HTML5 Today

Starting off with a brief history of the specifications that came before, Jeremy Keith gives an explanation on how the various working groups work along with how the specifications are created. This was really enlightening and goes a long way to explain the whys of many of the choices that have been made for HTML5.

After reading HTML5 For Web Designers and listening to Molly Holzschlag‚Äòs great talk at Future Of Web Design about the processes, blood, sweat and tears¬†of the working groups, I feel like I‚Äôm starting to get an idea of all the politics and diplomacy that goes into these specifications and I‚Äôve certainly gained an appreciation for the hard work that must go into them.

The phrase ‚Äò*paving the cowpaths*‚Äò is repeated throughout the book showing how HTML5 emphasises on taking the existing practices that web developers have formed, such as having <div id="header"> and <div id="footer"> at the top and bottom of pages, and making them fully fledged parts of the specification, as in <header> and <footer> tags. It really shows that this specification is taking a really reasonable look at the web around it and taking backwards-compatibility into mind.

There‚Äôs no overly lengthy passages on musts and must-nots. Each chapter is a whistle-stop tour through a few choice elements, their implementation and how you can include them today with backwards-compatibility (and slow browser take-up) in mind. Despite the HTML examples, I wouldn‚Äôt say this was the kind of book you need to read at a desktop to try it all out. More than anything it serves to give the reader a taste of things to come and an enthusiasm for what the future will bring.

The final chapter, Using HTML5 Today, ends on realistic ways us keen developers can start using HTML5 right away. It goes to show that, with the amount of new features you can easily implement, it wasn‚Äôt too soon to have a book on HTML5 before the specification is finalised.

Jeremy Keith writes in a fun yet informative tone that makes you feel like you‚Äôre learning a lot and are part of the cool crowd with a load of webby in-jokes as well. It‚Äôs one of the first skills-based books I‚Äôve managed to read from cover-to-cover in the last year due to its size and engaging readability. Totally recommend it.

item.title: Picking Fonts
item.description:
This little post is an extension of my post on Web Fonts.

Of late, some of the snobbier designers are whining that more fonts available will mean the web will get covered in horrible mis-use of fonts, unreadable body text and general ugliness.

I don‚Äôt think this is totally fair, but I‚Äôm sure some people might get confused by the variety of fonts that are around, so I thought I‚Äôd share a few things I try to keep in mind when choosing fonts:

Use appropriate fonts

Easily said, I know, but some fonts are clearly more suitable for particular designs than others. For example, you wouldn‚Äôt use a font that looks like it‚Äôs dripping blood on a corporate site, and you‚Äôd not use a handwriting-style font on a site about computer programming.

If you‚Äôre aiming for clean and modern, go sans-serif. If you‚Äôre looking for a slightly more traditional feel, go serif.

Don‚Äôt use more than two fonts

With all these cool fonts around, it‚Äôs easy to go over-the-top and try out loads at once. Unless you‚Äôre going for a Victorian poster style, I‚Äôd steer clear of the multi-font look.

It‚Äôs difficult to find two fonts that match each other well. You want to look for as similar shapes as possible, round fonts with other circle-based fonts, condensed fonts with other tall, thin fonts.

If you‚Äôre really struggling to combine two, just use a different weight or style for the heading, like bold or all uppercase.

Mark Boulton covers these kinds of combinations in his fantastic book, A Practical Guide to Designing For The Web.

Keep it in the family

The easiest way to find two fonts that suit each other is to take two from the same family. These are always designed around the same shapes so you know they‚Äôll look good next to each other. This is particularly useful if you want to mix serif and sans-serif fonts. For example, the Museo family. Museo Sans, Museo Serif and Museo Slab all look great used in any combination.

Use simple fonts for body text

Whatever you do, leave the fancy fonts for the headings. With body text (paragraph text,) you‚Äôre aiming for readability above all else. Using any kind of fancy, looping, scrawly, drippy, firey font here will make it hard to read and really distract the reader.

Use lovely long font stacks

Bear in mind that, whatever fancy web font method you use, there will always be a user that can‚Äôt see that font. It might be because their browser doesn‚Äôt have javascript turned on, or doesn‚Äôt support @font-face or doesn‚Äôt have the system font you specified. Solve this problem by using as many similar fonts as possible in your font stack.

For example, I want to use Museo Sans as my body font on this page. My code would look like:

body { font-family: "Museo Sans", "Perspective Sans", Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; }

  • Typekit will provide Museo Sans for me, so I‚Äôll put that first in my font stack.
  • In case the user doesn‚Äôt have javascript enabled (or uses Opera!) I‚Äôll specify an @font-face font I found on Font Squirrel, Perspective Sans.
  • For the rare case that don‚Äôt support Typekit or @font-face, I‚Äôll specify the system font Helvetica.
  • Just in case a user doesn‚Äôt even have Helvetica, I‚Äôll also specify the wildly popular system font, Arial.
  • And for the user who for some reason has only weird fonts I‚Äôve never heard of on their computer, I‚Äôll specify sans-serif, so at least I know that they‚Äôre not being delivered a serif font when I really fancied sans.

Not much effort, maximum kindness to the user.

Keep the poor Windows users in mind

Whichever fonts you choose, you want to make sure it looks good in as many browsers as possible. For us lucky mac users, the fonts tend to normally look smooth and light and lovely. Unfortunately many Windows users aren‚Äôt so lucky. Craggy, pixelly and oddly squashed-looking fonts are very common.

Many Windows people aren‚Äôt as fussy as me, or just don‚Äôt notice, but it‚Äôs really worth checking that what the Windows‚Äô users see is actually legible.

This quick little guide is just the beginning of all the things I try to consider when I‚Äôm choosing fonts to use on the web. A lot of it feels automatic, but when I really think about it, there‚Äôs all sorts of rules and theory I‚Äôm trying to apply to my choices. And that‚Äôs still not saying I always get it right. To a degree, it is still a subjective choice.

item.title: Web Fonts
item.description:
I‚Äôve got a new infatuation; web fonts. Since the second I heard about Typekit (and Fontdeck) last year I‚Äôve been giddy with excitement about being able to use more fonts on the web. Georgia just doesn‚Äôt cut it anymore. Even the introduction of ten new fonts to shake things up would have me flustered. Here‚Äôs a brief look at my experience of web fonts over the last year or so.

@font-face and Font Squirrel

Before Typekit, the situation around the CSS @font-face declaration started getting more attention. There was good support across all major browsers (and some of the oldies like Internet Explorers 6 & 7) for this cunning little declaration that allowed you to embed any font into your website. @font-face displayed fonts like we needed, displaying as real selectable text that remains accessible and index-able by search engines.

Despite being far easier to use, and more reliable, than the truly hideous (though handy at the time) Flash text-replacement methods like sIFR and Cuf√≥n, @font-face is a bit of a pain to implement. The CSS declarations themselves are fairly simple, but the amount of different font formats you need to include is pretty insane. You need to include .eot, .woff, .ttf and .svg formats of each font face. Not to mention that there‚Äôs no piracy protection on these font faces so, not only do you have to find all those different font formats, but you had to make sure you had the rights to distribute them as well (‚Äôcause everybody knows that piracy is mean.)

Then came along Font Squirrel.

A wickedly cool site that shows you a huge array of fonts that are licensed for @font-face use, complete with @font-face kits containing the fonts, the license, a demo HTML file and the CSS you need to implement great-looking web fonts using @font-face.

All you need to do is copy all the font files on to your site, and copy the CSS into your stylesheet:

```@font-face {

font-family: ‘QuicksandBook’;

src: url(‘Quicksand_Book-webfont.eot’);

src: local(‘‚ò∫’), url(‘Quicksand_Book-webfont.woff’) format(‘woff’), url(‘Quicksand_Book-webfont.ttf’) format(‘truetype’), url(‘Quicksand_Book-webfont.svg#webfontozh2o7Cr’) format(‘svg’);

font-weight: normal;

font-style: normal;

}```

and put the font into your font-family font stack:

h1 { font-family: 'QuicksandBook', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; }

Typekit

Font Squirrel was great but as most of the fonts are free, a large amount of the fonts are lacking a bit in quality. They just lack the care and attention a font gets from a very skilled type designer.

And that‚Äôs where Typekit makes things awesome.

I rarely buy fonts. I try to get away with system fonts, or free fonts, a lot of the time. As I¬†mostly work on the web, it never made sense to use fonts that weren‚Äôt web-safe. I‚Äôd only indulge in paid fonts (and still pretty cheap ones) when I was doing logo or print design. I would have loved to use the beautiful, unusual and quality fonts from proper font foundries. I subscribed to FontShop‚Äòs newsletters just so I could gaze longingly at the fonts that felt too good for me.

Typekit brings those to-die-for fonts from top quality foundries to the web with a teensy bit of javascript. Typekit showcases some of the most stunning fonts I‚Äôve ever seen and allows you to use them on your site in a way that is quick and easy, but still preserves the licensing and distribution control that the foundries and font designers need to keep them going.

Since Typekit has launched, they have added loads more fonts, and they just keep getting better. The libraries are easy to browse, using tags and your own text samples, and you can even view browser samples of each font so you can see how bad it‚Äôs going to look in Windows‚Äô browsers ;)

I use Typekit on my personal site, and this blog, and an increasing amount of client sites. The only downside is that, because the fonts are only licensed for the web, you can‚Äôt use them in Photoshop mockups or logo designs unless you buy the correct licensed version. However, if you‚Äôre like me, and trying to design in-browser more often, it‚Äôs absolutely perfect from start to finish.

Google Web Fonts, Fontdeck and Fonts.com

There are other services around offering the same kind of solution as Typekit. One is Google Web Fonts, who are working in collaboration with Typekit, and another is Fontdeck. I haven‚Äôt got an invite to Fontdeck yet, so I reckon that one will remain a mystery for a while longer, and I took a quick look at Google Web Fonts, which only serves open source fonts, and it looks pretty similar to Typekit but only has a limited amount of fonts at the moment.

I had a quick go on Fonts.com web fonts, and whilst the site design is a bit much, the service seems reasonable. It was a very straight-forward process picking and publishing the font I‚Äôd chosen to a site. However, the rendering of the font (Century Gothic) looked awful on Windows, despite being a system font that usually looked pretty decent. I‚Äôm not assuming that this is the situation with all fonts on Fonts.com, but not being able to preview it cross-browser at a glance seems like a disadvantage after the excellent previews on Typekit.

Overall, my preferred web font solution is definitely Typekit. The exciting thing is that new solutions keep popping up all time, so I‚Äôm sure the best is yet to come. For now, I have to do a complicated mix of Typekit, @font-face and standard system fonts to cover all bases so I‚Äôm really looking forward to the day we have a robust solution that does it all for me!

item.title: Autodesk SketchBook Pro
item.description:
I‚Äôve always been a kind-of arty person. I took Art at school, did an Art Foundation and a Graphics degree. I totally loved art when I was small, but as I‚Äôve got older, and more technology and web-obsessed, a lot of the old media went a bit out of the window.

Though I was still loving wireframing and taking notes by hand, I just threw all the paints out in frustration at how slow and difficult they were.

I‚Äôd seen the iPad apps available before launch, and Autodesk‚Äôs SketchBook Pro caught my eye. The idea of drawing on-screen is pretty appealing (I never really got the hang of the chunkiness of the Wacom tablet) and SketchBook Pro is better than I expected.

This is my most recent drawing:

I was sitting at the fishing lake at Longleat, sketching from a photo in Matt‚Äôs fishing magazine whilst he fishes. (And using the WordPress app for writing this, but that‚Äôs a story for another time.) Asides from the sunlight making it a bit tricky to see anything other than my greasy fingerprints, it felt incredibly natural painting with my finger. Some clever person has probably come up with a way of using a stylus but I think that might spoil some of the charm. Finger painting is a bit thick, blobby and impressionist. I‚Äôm actually surprised by how much this looks like if I‚Äôd painted it in acrylics.

SketchBook Pro uses gestures as naturally as any native iPad app. You use 3-finger tap to open the tools, 2-finger pinch and drag for resizing and moving the canvas on the screen (so you can zoom for the fiddly bits) and a 3-finger left-to-right drag to undo your last marks (and right-to-left for redo.) I‚Äôm usually a bit rubbish at remembering all these kind of gestures but they just feel so right that it‚Äôs easy.

The capabilities of the tools are just amazing for an iPad app.

The Brushes palette

The amount of elements you can combine to create your own style and perfect the texture and colour you want are just incredible. I‚Äôve not even tried everything yet, but some of my favourite elements are:

  • Radius‚Äîfor going from the rough fat splodges to the tiniest little pixels, this gives you very fine-tuned control though it can be tricky to accurately choose the right radius with the small slider (despite my little fingers)
  • Opacity‚Äîopacity of your brush. I reckon it‚Äôs best used at less than 100% to give a more realistic painting effect, the more solid your brush, the more it‚Äôll look like an old-school MS Paint picture!
  • Type of brush‚ÄîI‚Äôve been sticking with this fine paintbrush style for now. It‚Äôs a very predictable, softish round brush.
  • Colour palette‚Äîcolour selection that beats Photoshop. It‚Äôd be great to have an interface this good for Photoshop. You can be so specific in your colour choices and easily change by Hue, Saturation or Tone which is great if you‚Äôre creating gentle gradations.

The incredible Layers feature

You can only have five layers, but you can merge your layers together when you‚Äôve used all five to give you more control over editing work on a new layer.

In my fish picture, I started with some basic line-drawing and blocking out colour. Then on a layer above, I gave it a wash of light yellow with a big fat, mostly transparent, brush and set that layer to 50%. This made that wash more subtle, then I merged the layer down (I knew I wouldn‚Äôt need to finely edit this rough stuff later) to make my basic base layer.

The next layer I used to add some more fiddly detail and shadow. I kept this separate from the layer below for¬†if I wanted to go back and erase parts without wiping my base layer.

Then over the top, I tried to make the detail a bit more subtle and give the fish a slightly more realistic 3D multi-coloured appearance.

I‚Äôm pretty pleased with the overall effect and I‚Äôll definitely keep trying to practice drawing and sketching.

There are other features of SketchBook Pro as well! My sister liked the mirrored setting and another friend made a great landscape using textured brushes for plants and flowers. I‚Äôll also be looking out for further Autodesk apps as they seem to have the iPad interface totally nailed.

If you fancy getting a bit creative on the iPad, go download SketchBook Pro from the App Store. At ¬£4.99 it‚Äôs a steal. The amount of thought and skill gone into the user experience of the app makes it worth far more, and undoubtably more than many higher-priced apps.

item.title: Open In A New Window
item.description:
I‚Äôve been working with a client who wants every external link on their site to open in a new window. They dislike the idea of users leaving their site for somebody else‚Äôs and not being able to find their way back.

I understand their concern. I really do. It seems like a perfectly rational feeling but there are a few reasons why this generally isn‚Äôt the right thing to do.

  1. ### The Back button is the second most-used form of navigation.

If a user wants to go back to your site, they can. If you open in a new window or tab, you make the ‚ÄòBack‚Äô button useless. Don‚Äôt treat your users like they‚Äôre idiots that need to be led-around by the nose. (It helps to be helpful, but not patronising!)

  1. ### By opening a link in a new window, you‚Äôre not giving the user any other choice.

This is my personal pet hate. If I want to open a link in another window or tab, I can do so easily by right-clicking the link and selecting that option (and I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs numerous shortcuts for such behaviour.) However, if you specify that the link must open in another window, there‚Äôs nothing I can do about it. You shouldn‚Äôt force users into situations that are uncomfortable against their usual browsing patterns. They will end up associating that discomfort with your site.

  1. ### Some users just won‚Äôt understand what‚Äôs happening.

As more and more people get cheap access to the internet, there will be more users who have very basic skills, aren‚Äôt wholly computer-literate, but will browse your site anyway! If you‚Äôd never used a computer before, and were presented with a link that opened in a new window, are you sure you‚Äôd understand what just happened? These users may not understand that they‚Äôre now in a new window or tab. They‚Äôll have a great big ‚ÄòBack‚Äô button screaming at them, not a ‚ÄòClose this window or tab and then select the relevant window or tab to view it again‚Äô button.

  1. ### There‚Äôs no guarantee that, when the user closes that window, they‚Äôll go back to your site.

If I open a page in a new tab on Safari, it gets added to the end of my list of tabs. If I‚Äôve already got another tab open that has the BBC website in, when I close the new tab, it‚Äôll go back to the BBC website, not your website.

  1. ### It‚Äôs irritating for mobile browsers.

Some mobile browsers may just ignore your ‚ÄòOpen in New Window‚Äô suggestion as they don‚Äôt support multiple windows. If you‚Äôre browsing using Mobile Safari, it will do this very dramatic shrink-this-window open-another-window animation. The back button is much less fiddly. People using mobile browsers are more likely to be on-the-go and less likely to put up with switching windows all the time when browsing your site.

Please be considerate of your users, and don‚Äôt treat them like they don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre doing. For those that really don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre doing, keep it simple. If users remember yours as the site that was easy to use, that‚Äôs going to make you a lot more popular than forcing them to look at your content ever will.

Some other handy articles I found on this subject:

  • Should Links Open In A New Window Or Not?‚ÄîPro Blog Design
  • Open New Windows for PDF and other Non-Web Documents‚ÄîJakob Nielsen‚Äôs Alertbox
  • My CHI2010 talk: A Study of Tabbed Browsing‚ÄîPatrick Dubroy
  • Avoid Forcing To Open In A New Window‚ÄîWebnauts
  • The Top Ten Web Design Mistakes of 1999‚ÄîJakob Nielsen‚Äôs Alertbox
  • How Evil Is The Target Attribute?‚ÄîRobert‚Äôs Talk

item.title: Zootool ‚Äî The best and most beautiful tool for storing inspiration
item.description:
Since I started using Zootool in March I‚Äôve been totally addicted.

I‚Äôd been looking for a scrapbook-style app, to stash all the inspiration I find, for a while. On cool sites like Dribbble, Drawar, FFFFound and all over the web, I‚Äôm always finding pretty things I‚Äôd like to keep and use when I‚Äôm designing later on.

I was trying to do this with Little Snapper but found, whilst it‚Äôs great for posh and annotated screenshots, it wasn‚Äôt quick enough to capture and file the images and sites that I‚Äôd found. Previously I‚Äôd also tried Flickr, Skitch and even just saving image files in a folder on my hard drive. All were a nightmare to maintain and find the images after I‚Äôd stored them. Then a little ad with a pretty rhino popped up in Tweetie‚Äôs Fusion ads *.

Zootool captured me from the beginning with the mac-like, slick and incredibly useful interface. The lovely woodiness doesn‚Äôt look tacky, all the buttons and form elements work exactly as you expect. And it is unbelievably quick to capture an image, video, page or document using the bookmarklets provided¬†and then get back to what you‚Äôre doing.

And once you‚Äôve got a cool collection of images in your cutely named ‚ÄòZoo‚Äô, you can browse by category, tag or just search to find them again. All in an interface that feels like a desktop app but in-browser.

It‚Äôs not really restricted to scrapbook-style use either. I was surprised to find that other people use it for just saving funny videos (my tunnel vision just saw how perfect it was for saving lovely pictures and thought everyone would use it for that) and you can import all your Delicious bookmarks to use it as a visual bookmark browser.

The amount of tags can feel restrictive, as it‚Äôs only ten per item, but then again I‚Äôm a taxonomy addict. I‚Äôve started using a tag of @origin (@dribbble, @ffffound, @twitter) as well to make sure I remember where I found the image or site in the first place in case I need to give proper attribution.

Zootool also has special versions for iPhone and iPad (though for some reason I can‚Äôt scroll on the iPad version,) where native mac-ness of the design is really clear, there‚Äôs a Flickr-style badge that‚Äôs perfect for a blog (see below!) and you can even also use Fluid app to pretend it‚Äôs a real desktop app whenever you‚Äôre connected to the internet. I use Fluid with the MobileMe Olive theme that looks lovely against the Zootool design.

These are just a few of the numerous tools available that you can use with Zootool, and all for free. In case you couldn‚Äôt guess by the gushingness of this post, I really really thoroughly recommend it to anybody wanting to keep a collection of inspirational images.

Note: I was really lucky to meet¬†Bastian Allgeier, the creator of Zootool, at Future Of Web Design this year and tell him how much I love it, and great to see his hard work acknowledged by¬†Jon Hicks on stage.

* I keep the ad-supported version of Tweetie for this reason, the ads are usually for top-quality, useful products.
